There are many places for dim sum in China Town, and for more than half my life I have chosen this particular restaurant. And as much as it hurt to write this review it will hurt even more to find a new place.More

title: Best value in Chinatown
review: I think this place is the best value in Chinatown.  A LOT of places in Chinatown are marked up big time because of it being a tourist attraction. Not so here.   The food is ALWAYS good here as is the service too:)  I've been going...here for years. I don't live in the area anymore but I still visit on occasion.  The BBQ Pork, Crab Rangoon and Egg Roll appetizers are killer! All of the entrees I've tried are very good too.  Friendly service and always a kettle of tea with the meal too:)  Check it out!More

title: Great Food - That's all you need
review: The old huge Three Happiness was torn down and they are now located in a small storefront on Cermak.  We loved dim sum at the old restaurant and we almost didn't go in since it didn't really look like it could be the same.  We...More

title: Cantonese.
review: Nationwide Cantonese restaurants are getting rarer to find. I believe cooks are dying off and the tradition isn't being passed on. They're still carrying on the tradition here. The restaurant is awfully small but they did have the NFL on the big screen.  I wasn't...More

title: Large portions !
review: My husband and I flew in after midnight and checked into our hotel. The front desk recommended this place to eat since it is open into the wee hours. Service was good and the food seemed very fresh. I enjoyed the wonton soup! The portions...More

title: Losing it's touch
review: I have been a faithful patron of this establishment 2or 3 times a week for 20 years. Needless to say every restaurant has its ups and downs but here I'm saddened. Food and service used to be great. Now it's just average. You used to...More

title: I don't get it
review: Went here because of so many positive reviews but did not enjoy the food. I was bombarded with 3 menus, the largest menu looked to be about 20 years old with hundreds of items. They do not have ice tea only Coke and Pepsi, these...More

title: Chinese, Chinese, Chinese
review: Chinatown has a lot of dining options and Three Happiness is the best for the price.  Inexpensive, large servings and numerous options are the highlights.  Hot and sour soup was delicious.

title: Hole in the wall,but fantastic food
review: Had to go to china town so hopped on the red line and was there in 10 mins from where I was staying,heard the food was great and it is better then great! we had  a hot chicken dish,fried rice,some sort of pork dish and...More

title: Great food
review: Was undecided on where to eat. We decided to stop by here, the place is small. The food is very good. I ordered the family meal deal for two. It seemed more like family deal for 4. Ha ha .Huge portions, lots of leftovers.  The...More

title: Quite allright
review: Tipically Chinese food. Quick service and menu's with pictures. Let the personel advice you on your choice, because the pictures are hard to interpret.

title: Chinese food - 24 hours
review: Not every restaurant in Chinatown is open 24 hours, but if you have a craving for Chinese food in the middle of the night, Three Happiness is one very good possibility.  It is a small restaurant, but it works.  I particularly love the shrimp fried...More

title: HIDDEN GEM
review: This is the best hidden gem if your a native Chicagoan or Tourist this is a must go to This is the real deal and you will be satisfied

title: Ask for it, Not on the Carry Out Menu
review: PAN FRIED NOODLES with BBQ PORK and or CHICKEN. Either would be great or both in the brown gravy and stir fried veggies & meat over the pan fried thin noodles. It should be eaten when you want something mild but Tasty. Yum.

title: Best Chinese food I ever had
review: I have had Chinese food before but nothing compares to how good this place is. I always past by this place but finally stop in and best choice I made. There shrimp toast is amazing and a must try appetizer. Best fried rice I ever had and can't wait to go back and try some more. If your in the area a must try for sure!

title: One of The Best in Chinatown
review: Nothing exceptionally fancy, but the food makes up for it. Small in stature but huge on menu, and flavor. The other thing I like is, I work nights, and it's open 24 hours a day. I was born and raised around the Chinatown neighborhood,we (friends and family) ate there a lot. This is defiantly one of my favorite places.

title: Asian Adventure
review: Absolutely charming little restaurant. No frills. Very simple and excellent Asian cuisine. Dim Sum, Chicken fried rice, Pork and peppers. Sesame Balls. (YUM).Small rest rooms. I mean real small. Not ADA by any means. Great stop for lunch.

title: Very nice in Chicago Chinatown
review: Had a nice experience in this place.  Small place but big menu. Very nice waitstaff and reasonable prices.  Highly rated by other dining apps tried it and was pleased.

title: Authentic dim sum
review: Food was good,  service was always around. A few time we were not sure what we were eating tbough. This type of place can get pricy fast so pay attention.

title: Interesting
review: Visited this restaurant on recommendation. A most interesting place small doesn't seem to have had a visit from an inspector in a while. The menu offered a lot. We opted for egg roll (spring roll) chicken curry (what can I say Irish on tour). The meal was a generous portion I seem to have got all the onion in Chinatown that day. Despite this it was well flavoured (no artificial flavour). The service was prompt and friendly. If its recommended to you don't let the exterior fool you. Give it a go.

title: Cute little place...
review: While visiting Chicago I thought it'f be nice to stop by chinatown for a little bit. This restraunt is a nice little place to sit and grab some (delicious!) orange chicken. Im not big on chinese food, but it was pretty decent. Not a MUST go, but it's still some yummy food :)

title: Ë¶ã„Åã„Åë„Å®„ÅØÈÅï„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô
review: not expensive friendly atmosphere. I'm satisfied with spring rolls.

title: Awful
review: if you like low quality meat with major food enhancer this the place, greasy and overpriced. Three happiness is a Chinese restaurant , but without the true Chinese cooking.

title: Disappointing
review: Came here on Christmas Day as most restaurants in city centre were either closed / expensive. Based on reviews we narrowed down either here or Phoenix round the corner. A local told us that Phoenix had an hour wait so we opted for Three Happiness, and even though the restaurant and everywhere else was busy we were seated straight away. We were also given chinese tea and water on arrival (which were great little touches). However when it came to ordering we were really put off. The menu selection was really good and even though there was only 2 of us we wanted to order about 7/8 dishes (and was willing to take back to hotel). However about 4 dishes in the guy told us we were ordering too much food and when I said we would bag up the leftovers he got really defensive and funny with us. That didn't go down well, and when the food came out it was slow between dishes (rather than together) and in a random order (for example rice first then 5 mins later we would got our meat). We actually didn't receive one dish in the end which I asked to be taken off the bill. I expected it to be busy which it was but you could see with floods of people coming in and takeaway orders too, the staff were completely overwhelmed to stay on top. The quality of the food we did get was ok and the prices are very good, however it was a shame as we thought this place would be a hidden gem and after not receiving half the food we wanted, I regret coming here and wish I waited the extra time at phoenix.

title: Great Spot in China Town!!
review: Don't be fooled by the exterior, this is a must do for lunch! 10 minute cab ride from the Mag Mile and worth it. Enjoy China Town and the great atmosphere and energy. Order #1!! Also get the sticky rice with meat wrapped in a huge leaf!! So good. Very clean and quick attentive service!!

title: Very good, inexpensive food in a no-frills joint.
review: The Three Happiness Original restaurant (not to be confused with the New Three Happiness restaurant across the street on the north side of Cermak Ave.) is a hole-in-the-wall storefront operation in the heart of Chinatown. The dining area is small and unembellished.On a recent weekday our group of four lunched there. We all shared the shrimp with black bean sauce, the satay beef, the chicken with cashews, and the pork fried rice. When the food arrived, we initially thought that we had ordered too much as the portions were quite ample. However, the food was so good that hardly a scrap was left over. All the dishes were well prepared and tasty, but I especially liked the shrimp because of its very flavorful sauce. The service was efficient and courteous.Pay-to-park lots and metered street parking are available. Weekends in Chinatown are usually very crowded so plan accordingly.The Three Happiness is recommended for the good quality of the food and its moderate prices, but go elsewhere if you are looking for a classy atmosphere.

title: My family favorite
review: I've been coming to this restaurant with my family for the passed 23 years. My grandfather used to bring my dad and his siblings here when they were younger. The food is great. I always order a small bowl of won ton soup. The family tends to order the same plates. Beef and broccoli, with American broccoli. Sweet and sour chicken. Shrimp fried rice. Every once in a while we get the pork dumplings. The food isn't salty and we never receive it cold. The employees are very attentive and friendly. It is a family run business and I always love supporting businesses like that. Don't confuse this place with the other 3 happiness that is across the street on the same side of the fire station.

title: Great dim sum! Great value!
review: We thoroughly enjoyed our dim sum, with most of our choices being only $2! Don't look for fancy! I was touched as I watched the lady who was serving at the time let an older man come in, pay for a meal with pocket change, and helped him dish up his noodles and broth. Yes, there were extension cords coming out of the kitchen to power the cooler in the small dining area. And yes there was very little English spoken. But the food was great! My favorite was the sticky rice and pork wrapped in a lotus leaf! Our server taught us how to unwrap the leaf and unveil the goodness inside! Come expecting great food but not expecting fancy ambiance. The food and the people there make the restaurant!

title: Cheap, tastes great, open very late
review: Worth the drive to Chinatown, our favorite is the Salt & Pepper Pork Chop and Duck Fried Rice. People always coming in to order, but able to find a seat without a wait. Parking easier to find at later hours. Our favorite spot for Chinese food.

title: Three plus 10+happiness
review: Frankly, I'm not crazy about this place, but my husband thinks its heaven on earth! It's kind of a hole-in-the-wall place, maybe 10 tables total, and two of them are typically taken by the staff/family that runs the place. He is a nut, so take his experiences with a grain of salt! He drives over an hour to eat Sunday morning Dim Sum there with our son who lives in Chicago. The goofball comes back talking about how cool it was to eat a delicious meal with Hong Kong news in the background, and the staff bantering back and forth about who knows what ! He is also a bit of a tight-wad, and so he raves about how much delicious food he consumed for less money than he expected to pay. It makes me happy to see him so happy when he comes back from his Three Happiness experience, so I highly recommend the place !

title: Decent Cantonese in Chicago's Chinatown
review: Do not confuse this Three Happiness with the identically named restaurant across the street on the corner of Wentworth and Cermak (with a Wentworth address). Although at one point I believe there was a relationship between the two, they are no longer connected and I believe there are legal actions going on about the fact that both have the same name. The larger Three Happiness on Wentworth has excellent dim sum, though everything else there is ordinary. I haven't had dim sum at this location (and don't know if they serve it), but the regular Cantonese fare is decent but ordinary. There are many better choices (Phoenix, Cai) for this type of cuisine in Chicago's Chinatown, with more crisp and fresher vegetables and less tired ingredients. In addition, service here can be slow and even grumpy. Some dishes (chow fun, for example) are above average, but on the whole this is neither particularly good nor particularly bad.

title: Deem Sum in Chicago
review: On the Corner of Cermack and Wentworth at the Gateway to Chinatown was the restaurant.  The deem sum fare was excellent.  Many of the waitresses are trilingual, Cantonese, Mandarin and English!!!  Ate till our hearts!! content!!

title: "Little" Three Happiness is worth a visit
review: First of all, the place is a bit of a dump. One's got to turn sideways to get through the tiny doors to the bathroom. It's hard to find a place to park on the street and street meter parking is expensive. On the way to and from the restaurant there's a good chance a panhandler will ask for money. And believe me when I say all the hassles are worth it. The food here is wonderfully tasty and extremely moderately priced. Try the egg rolls, which are HUGE and oh-so-good. Here's all one really needs to know about this place...it's where Chicago police come to get carry-out during their breaks while on duty, especially late at night and well after midnight. You'll feel stuffed when you leave and you may want to thumb your nose at the much-more-expensive restaurants in the area that have a lot more atmosphere. I've been here countless times when passing through Chicago at all hours and the stop is always worth it. Just be sure to go to the Three Happiness on the south side of the street, across from the fire department. The identically-named restaurant on the north side is MUCH larger and seems to be geared more to tourists. This is a restaurant where the local Chinatown residents come to eat.

title: Dim Sum and large portions
review: The dim sum here is great. The servers bring it out in carts and there is no wait for what you want to order. Be careful the time of day that you go, if it is a bit slow, the dim sum might have been sitting on the cart a bit too long. I have eaten here many times and I love the food, the service is good, and the restaurant and bathrooms are clean. There is even a decent view. Speak clearly to the servers as most of them speak only broken English. If you order something off of the menu, the portion size is huge. Plan on sharing or taking half of it home. The price is great too. Two of us can eat dim sum and drink oolong tea until we are stuffed for about $15. If you are in the area, I definitely recommend stopping in!

title: Not for "Panda Express" fans. Real deal Chinese food, not Americanized at all.
review: So you want to go to Chinatown and feel like you are in China? Go here for a true blue collar lunch. Normal to not so normal dim sum selections, ie. Chicken feet, fried quail. Great congee soup. Great bargain and big portions. It is a hole in the wall, but don't let that stop those of you with an adventurous palate.

title: Two restaurants with the same name here!
review: A friend told me to go here when visiting Chinatown...so we got to Cermak and low and behold there are 2 restaurants with the same name! Not knowing I checked a review site on my phone and chose the one on Cermak about 3 doors down from the entrance to Chinatown...the sign says "cantonese". I found out later that my friend goes to the other one. The place is small...about 8 tables and is sort of a "diner" atmosphere - not really authentic Chinese at all (big screen tv on wall). Not having a clue what we were doing, we ordered a bunch of food from the dim sum menu....way too much food! We got enough food to feed 8 people for $54 which is a great value and most of the food was pretty darn good with a couple of exceptions. All in all we were happy and stuffed but next time we go, we'll check out the other Three Happiness no the corner and see how they compare.

title: THREE HAPPINESS ON CERMAK
review: While visiting Chicago I attended my first White Sox game. Since I took Chicago's "Red Line" light rail to get to the game and back I noticed that the first stop just north of U.S. Cellular Field is Chicago's Chinatown. Being from Los Angeles, I like Chinese food and decided to try one of the Chinese restaurants there.I explored the area on foot and chose the Three Happiness Restaurant on Cermak Road. I point that out because there is another Chinese restaurant called Three Happiness that is within eyesight of this one but on a different street. The other one is a much larger building.I was pleasantly surprised at the little hole in the wall Three Happiness on Cernak. I had the Hunan Beef and it was very good. In fact I went back a second time before I left Chicago and before another White Sox game. However, both times I went were for lunch and I got the feeling that the neighborhood probably would not be too safe after dark.

title: Very good food, lot of locals
review: Good food at extremely reasonable prices.  Needs a good cleaning though.  Authentic, plentiful Cantonese style Chinese food in a casual setting.

title: Cold food is not good
review: We were looking for a good place to eat Dim Sun in Chicago's China Town. We saw great reviews about this restaurant, so decided to give it a try. We were very dissappointed when most of the food we got was cold.We've usually seen that great Chinese restaurants usually attract Chinese customers, and in this case most of the customers were not Chinese... does this say something to you, too?

title: good meal
review: Small, poorly kept place with 9 tables. Soup was very good but main courses were overly drenched in sauces. Even so, it wasn't a bad meal, just too heavy on the sauces. Entertainment for the night was being accosted by a panhandler while at our table.

title: Duck fried rice or just rice
review: The only reason why I go here is for the duck fried rice but lately they have been adding more rice than duck!?!? The place is extremely small, service is kinda slow, price is cheap! I'll have to venture out and see who else has good duck fried rice

title: why would you go there when you have so many choice in chinatown?
review: This place is old and food is not good, I am a Chinese, half my life in HK half my life in Chicago, this is not the choice you wanna pick when you travel all the way to chinatown! If you want dim sum--go to Phoenix, MingHin, or the ShuWai, if you want authetic chinese food, go to Go4food.

title: One of the worse!
review: First off there are 2 restaurants called three Happiness litterally across from each other in Chinatown so some readers might get them both confused. We ventured into little three hapiness which is the smaller of the two and not a place I would recomend at all. Service was awful and the food was mediocre at best. My daughter had the fried shrimp and she could not finish the first piece it was so awful. Sweet and sour chicken was not good and left us needing tums after and the curry chicken was average. Our one good plate of food was the lemon chicken. Prices were average but do yourself a favor and go someplace else..

title: Not the best dim sum I've ever had but pretty good.  SO cheap!  Two of us dined for a whopping $11.
review: Not the best dim sum I've ever had but pretty good.  SO cheap!  Two of us dined for a whopping $11.

title: I like it for the dim sum, - I haven't had anything else there.
review: I like it for the dim sum, - I haven't had anything else there.

title: The food was average and...
review: The food was average and the service was really slow. luv the egg custard dim sum

title: WOW!!!!!!!!!
review: After going to some restaurants in Chinatown i wass pretty disapointed; when i went to Little Three Happiness... well lets just say you HAVE to get the Salt and Pepper Scallops. you definetly have to get it... if you are looking for a fancy restaurant it is not the place to go but if you want quality food that taste good this is the place to go.

title: Dead Spider In My Food - Not Kidding
review: I've heard this place is dirty but after finding a dead spider cut in half at the bottom of my soup, I didn't realize just how dirty they are. Chicago health inspector has been called on them before and I called this time for the spider.

title: Bakery visit
review: Stopped and went inside, bought 2 pork buns, 1 lotus cake and 1 winter melon cake.  The baked items were OK.

title: Hong Kong style bakery, fast service, great buns and tarts, bring cash.
review: Been here many times! Buns are great, castard tarts, coconut tarts, cake rolls, foonrolls!Manny different types of buns with different fillings, Dont forget to try the milk tea Hong Kong style. Very limited dim sum selection. You can sit down , enjoy a bun , cakes, bubble tea and other beverages. One negative- they don‚Äôt take credit or debit cards! Cash is king. Good place to visit. Enjoy!

title: SWEETS!!!!
review: All too pretty to eat! But we must choose. I got rice ball with red bean paste in the middle. Also a piece of the most delicious cheesecake I probably ever had. I would shop here every day.

title: Delicious tortes and cake
review: Good tortes and egg custard.  For their tortes the sponge cake is very light and moist, and their whipped cream is delicious.  They use an assortment of fresh fruits in their torte filling and toppings.  The counter people are always friendly.

title: Yummy authentic Chinese pastries and more!
review: We stopped here on a Chicago Food Planet tour; we just had one pastry but it was delicious, an egg custard pastry. There were many others int he pastry case I would have liked to try and I regret not getting the coconut cookies to munch on later! There milk tea was also quite good and not too sweet.

title: Good bakery, milk tea and snack
review: Been to saint anna many times. It seems it is always busy and the ladies behind the counter are fast, one does not even need a calculator to sum up your purchase. Buns, tarts, cakes, Hong Kong style milk tea. Light snacks , rice rolls filled with shrimp, pork of beef. Good place to rest up for a snack and have a cold/ hot drink and people watch. Oh, don't forget the cake rolls they are GREAT! You can even freeze some the BBQ pork buns and they are delicious when you reheat them in the microwave. Their egg tarts are best in Chinatown. Coconut tarts are wonderful as well if you like coconut. Will go back again and again. Yum yum yum yum

title: Forget the fancy Chinese places, gives this place a try!
review: We were on a tour of Chinatown and were extremely hungry, with so many choices we were overwhelmed but someone in our party suggested this place for lunch. At first we were hesitant as the name says it is a bakey and we couldn't tell they actually had food other than sweets plus it was small and not fancy at all. Well.. we were thrilled. The food was fantastic we had the dumplings, chicken wings, fried rice and two specialty noodles (flat noodles with seafood and pork noodles). Wish we would've had room for desserts but were full from the great meal. Better yet I think our bill was under $60 for 7 of us. But please be aware this is a Cash Only place.. only draw back!

title: Sweet treats!
review: Nice assortment of sweets at cheap prices.  Hubby got cheesecake with blueberry topping...$2.95 for a good sized slice.   I got the fruit tart for around $2.  Both very tasty! A nice lace to stop and take a break while exploring Chinatiwn!

title: Tasty Sesame Balls
review: My daughter and I are particiculary partial to Sesame Balls especially if they have red bean filling. The ones at Saint Anne's are perfect! For some reason most of the Sesame Balls I have had the past couple of years have not had red bean filling...a true disappointment for me. When I read that Sain Anne's had the ones I wanted, I made sure to visit the bakery.I was so pleased with them that we went twice in one week.In addition, I highly recommend the egg tarts. Beautiful flaky crisp shell with a silky custard filling. Delicious.

title: Good Chinese Bakery
review: They have a good selection of Chinese buns like barbecue pork and cream buns.  They are tasty but the bread is drier.  The egg tarts are good and is more flavorful than others.  The ladies behind the counter are always friendly.

title: Most Authentic Hong Kong Style Tea Cafe
review: If you ever wonder down to Chicago Chinatown, most definitely should go visit St. Anna.  This is the most authentic HK style tea caf√© here.  The milk tea and the pastry are excellent, the cost is cheap. Food and drink recommended: HK style milk tea,...More

title: Strawberry boba tea stop
review: Needed a drink so bought the strawberry boba tea.  It was $3.50 and the cup was a decent sized cup.  A bunch of the restaurants in Chinatown were selling for $3.50.  I like to support the local little businesses so I didn't go to the...More

title: Nice quick stop for a treat
review: We stopped in for a look see as I wanted my partner to see some different food. He's not very adventurous with his food.  He did try an egg tart - which he loved... and I admit they were very good. He also tried a...More

title: perfect place for pastries
review: I went here twice when on a trip to Chicago. Sesame buns were delicious as well as the green tea mousse cake. The service was incredible

title: Portions much smaller
review: haven't been to this bakery in a while, which we have patronized tons of times in past.  portions now seem much smaller,  at a higher cost.  not worth it.  but maybe it's the trend now a days?

title: Great chinese bakery
review: You need cash for this place, but boy, you need to try their pork bbq bun, they are great for snack time and even for lunch or dinner! the sauce is great which is already inside the bun! Best chinese buns I've tasted.  Their ham...More

title: Nice little bakery in Chinatown
review: Came here because I was craving bubble tea at 10:30 am before Joy Yee was open. I was so glad I came, they served breakfast, had nice selection of pastries, breads and cakes. Cute little place.  Cash only.

title: Great Custard
review: The egg custard was great, very light and not too sweet. If you don't like egg taste its not the best recommendation, but there are plenty of sweet treats to choose from

title: Egg custard pastry
review: A day trip in Chinatown won't be complete without stopping by this bakery and pick up some pastries to take home. The egg custard pastry is tasty and moist which goes well with hot tea. It is worth the pit stop.

title: the best pastries in China Town
review: OMG, the best almond cookies ever.  A trip to China town is not complete without a stop here. Have been enjoying the Asian and Continental bakery goods for 15 years.  Last year, at a group birthday dinner, one of my friends when to St. Anna...More

title: Delicious & Beautiful
review: Our last stop on the Chinatown Food Planet Tour.  Yummy delicious desserts...the egg custard pastry was amazing!  The pastry shelves are full of beautiful tasty treats...eat in or take home

title: very deceitful
review: ordered delivery but had a 17 dollar missing! Call no answer. What a piece of crap! Dirty restaurant, probably cheated customers many times. Need investigations!

title: Authentic Korean
review: We had Bibimbap. Cooked in a stone bowl so the rice on the bottom becomes crispy. Many side dishes like in Korea. Red paste added to dish. Not too spicy. Reminded us of our visit to Korea in May.

title: Abusive Manager
review: I was in the restaurant. Manager answered phone and shouted a moment later, "I don't give a f*cking crap about your parking problem. Get in here and pick up the delivery!" After he disconnected the call, the phone rang and he shouted again, "I don't give a f*cking crap!" As he hung up again, we walked out and will never return. Who treats their workers like this??? Obviously this man does!

title: Surprisingly not spicy and not that impressive
review: We ate dinner here due to rave reviews, but were pretty surprised at how average it was. The restaurant was full and the food seemed to take quite a while to get to the table. We were warned that the spicy chicken wings were super spicy, and were disappointed that they were hardly spicy at all. The side dishes were not up to par, but were average. The Boodae Jun-gol was our adventurous choice, a serviceman's stew that had processed US flavors including instant ramen, spam, and sausages, was an interesting choice with a lot of sodium, but we knew that it would be already. Maybe we ordered the wrong items, but the bulgogi, the pork belly did not stand out for flavor. Overall, it was not what we expected.

title: AMAZING
review: We love to try new types of food and wanted a different type of restaurant. Walking in we had no idea what to order or how the dishes worked but everything smelled amazing!!! We ordered a seafood soup for 2. OMG! The flavours and spice were absolutely outstanding. The price is excellent for food and drinks. The servers are amazing! Ours spoke English and was very helpful. They are attentive to the table and to our needs.

title: Wonderful unique food near South Loop, McCormick Place
review: I love Ajoomah's Apron. Went first for book club after reading Pachinko, a novel about Korea. Went again a few days later with my husband and it was excellent both times. Was a great experience: the ambience, the wait staff, the delicious, unique flavors, the price. Such an easy walk from South Loop or McCormick Place. $2 validated parking for 3 hours at closeby Chinatown parking lots if you need to drive. Lunch specials are less than $10 and that includes 8 dishes of unique Korean sides. Loved the fish cakes (very mild and flavorful) and the potatoes (sweet and white in a lovely seasoned sauce). My main dish was the Jajangmyun, a black bean dish with potatoes, zucchini and onions. Friends got the BibimBop, a beautiful bowl of mixed veggies, rice and protein of your choice with a fried egg on top. Another friend had the breaded chicken with veggies which looked like a schnitzel with panko bread crumbs: gorgeous presentation. Everyone loved everything and we were mostly all new at Korean food.I highly recommend Ajoomah's Apron and plan to be a lunch regular. Go!

title: Delicious Kimchi!
review: I googled "best Korean restaurant in Chicago" and this the is restaurant that popped up so we decided to try it. I went with my wife and her parents. Right after we were seated, a whole soccer team came in, so the service was a bit slow but due to the large party seated at the same time as us. However, we were served eight different side dishes that we snacked on while we waited for our orders. The kimchi served as a side dish was definately the best kimchi I have ever had. I ordered the stir-fried squid and pork upon recommendation from the waiter. For some reason, my food did not come out with the rest of my party's food and I had to wait some time for my food. However, the waiter did sincerely apologize several times and offered me more side dishes along with a free drink for my wait. Once my food did come, it was quite good. The pork and squid were not overcooked and the sauce was delicious. The rest of my party enjoyed their food as well. I don't know if I would say this is the BEST Korean restaurant in Chicago (I mean I haven't eaten at them all yet), but the kimchi is the best I have ever had. I would say that the food is good and is reasonably priced, but they could still improve on the service aspect.

title: Slow service and spicy low quality food
review: We went with a couple of friends to Ahjoomah's Apron today. The menus were hard to understand because the English description were really vague. The service was slow and the food seemed like a bad quality food, very spicy and hard to eat. The prices were expensive !!!Also, in the middle of our lunch, a guy that was probably drunk came in and started yelling around sentences that were inappropriate for the kids. I would not recommend it.

title: Went on a walk and ended up at this resteraunt
review: This place is a little withdrawn from the outside but the food is amazing and the staff follows that up. Id for sure return.

title: Average Korean Food, Subpar Service & Ambiance
review: Maybe being a Korean restaurant in the heart of Chinatown was an omen, but unfortunately Ahjoomah's was quite mediocre. While the selection is quite good, there is nothing special about the various entrees. We were a group of five and all were in agreement the food was average however the service was poor. With so many choices in the city, no reason to seek this spot out.

title: Don't go here, food was burned and service very slow
review: Heard great things about the restaurant. Went and it was half full. The service was very bad and slow. Took a long time to order, to get the sides - banchan and to get refills on water. Small group. Food came out burned - half was cooked ok and the other half burned. Ordered meat dishes and pancake.

title: Home Style Cooking
review: Go to Chinatown for great Korean cooking.  Street parking on Cermak Boulevard. Diverse menu. Many specialties some of which are less expensive at lunch. Nice interior. Great service.

title: As good as it gets in Chicago
review: We stop in regularly for the excellent Korean food. Service is great and the beer is authentic. Kim chi is made locally and aged to perfection.

title: Korea in China
review: My favourite Korean place in Chicago is in Chinatown. It is small and always busy at peak hours. I love kimchi and their assortment is outstanding. I have eaten their several times and have yet to be disappointed.

title: Great Korean food in Chicago's Chinatown
review: I came here for the Korean beef stew (yuk gejjang) and it was extremely delicious. The side dishes were also very good. Highly recommended!

title: Korean Food!
review: The food was delicious. The mandu and mackerel were excellent. The side dishes were fresh and delicious, as well.

title: Authentic
review: Decent Korean BBQ - galbi was really good but the bonchon dishes tasted a little weird to me, not as good as Texas Korean food that I'm used to. The prices were good though, service was good - so overall I would come here again for authentic Korean BBQ. Just not the best but not many options in Chicago downtown area.

title: Great Food but Worst Service I've Ever Had. EVER.
review: This is a very small but busy restaurant. The food is very good and the prices are reasonable. But the service is terrible. The servers are all young, and all forgetful. After being seated, we waited a long time before anyone came back to the table, even though there are only about 12 tables in the place. In the end, we had to go ask for menus. Then we ordered drinks. I asked for some hot tea. Had to ask twice, even though the table next to us, who came in after us, got their tea almost immediately. When the food came, it was good, but we had to ask for everything even though we had said that we intended to share every dish we had ordered. Please can we have plates. Please can we have bowls for the soup. Please can we have a ladle for the soup. When they asked if we'd like more drinks, we ordered more water and another hot tea. The water came immediately. I had to ask for the tea 3 times but it still never came. I gave up in the end. We didn't have to ask twice for the check though. That came PDQ! Along with 2 mints, even though there were 3 of us at the table. That's what I mean about the service. The staff just weren't paying attention, weren't listening, weren't thinking.So bottom line, even though the food was good, I would not go back. Worst service ever.

title: My #1 for Korean cravings
review: If you're looking for the typical K-BBQ joint, this isn't necessarily the place for you. Some of the Korean restaurants cater too heavily for my taste to the BBQ-seeking patron. Ahjoomah's apron makes many of the authentic home-cooking Korean dishes that I crave. Excellent soups and stews, jjang-jjang-myun, of the course the bibimbap and seafood pancakes are delicious. I wish they'd open another restaurant outside of Chinatown!!

title: Reasonable Price; Decent Korean Food
review: Great Korean restaurant with reasonable everything--reasonable price; reasonable food (our party ordered quite a variety of dishes--bulgogi; kalbi; seafood hot pot; bibimbop; seafood pancake, etc); reasonable ambience. I also like that they use sesame oil instead of soy/corn oil like many other Asian restaurants do. If you feel like Korean food in Chicago, it's not a bad place to check out at all.

title: Great Korean food in of all places, Chinatown!
review: I was in Chicago for a few days on business and was hungry for some Korean food. Lo and behold, Ajoomah's Apron was so close to hotel that I could walk there in 10-15 minutes. This place is on Cermak Road just a block a way from the Red Line train at the edge of Chinatown (Cermak/Chinatown Station).I was seated right away and decided to order my favorite, Duk Mandoo Gook (dumplings with rice cake in soup). Within a few minutes, the waiter brought me my side dishes, all of which were quite flavorful.Ten minutes or so later, my main course arrived. One thing about this kind of entree is that the soup makes it or breaks it. In this case, the soup itself was phenomenal. You could taste a bit of pepper that added a lot of zest while not masking all the other flavors. The dumplings were good as well as the rice cake.I would definitely come back here again. The service was great and the food was fantastic. My meal came out to just over $12 + tip. Great find in Chinatown!

title: Tasty
review: Ahjoomah's Apron is located on Cermak across from the Chinatown gate. The interior is clean and cute. We ordered the fried chicken (awesomely spicy, worth the stickiness) jampong (actually made correctly with crab and other seafood bits) and galbi bibimbap. Only the bibimbap could have been a little more flavorful - but I think we're used to a particularly flavorful place in South Bend. Banchan was solid. Kimchi was good.The only inauthentic thing about this place is that the service was good and our waiter was super friendly...no salty "ahjoomahs" here. We'll be back.

title: Great food
review: I was in town for a couple of days and have never really eaten Korean food before. I was not disappointed. Hopefully, I'll eventually learn how this place stacks up against others, but it was definitely delicious.

title: Korean restaurant in south Chicago, China Town
review: It was pleasant surprise to find a very good Korean restaurant in south chicago neighborhood. They have a small menu, but the food is excellent !! They serve the best Bibim Bop !!!! It is also BYOB, which I think is more appropriate for their setting. They concentrate on excellent traditional Korean food. The location is just off Cermank train station. It is now my go to Korean restaurant :)

title: Good Korean food in town
review: I was visiting Chicago for a conference. This place is accessible from downtown Chicago by L, red line. We had galbi, spicy squid, and seafood hot pod. Foods were very good, authentic, and the service was also good.

title: interesting place that may getter better over time
review: I was looking for a Korean restaurant near my hotel near Chinatown. Service was friendly but not completely accurate as the waiter misheard one of our orders and brought the wrong dish and seemed a little upset about it. He didn't check back for us very much in the beginning to get our order in after we ordered appetizers first. Seating is pretty uncomfortable as all the tables only have benches. I snagged the first table near the window that allows you to lean against the wall. Yelp has a coupon for a free Korean drink which is very interesting - a very pulpy juice from a can. Definitely good large servings - we brought home leftovers. Bulgogi and Kalbi were good. chopchae was okay. Tofu soup was good. Sides were okay but would have preferred a different variety such as kimchi radishes.

title: Absolutely lovely spicy korean food.
review: I saw this little gem while passing by in China Town. It is hard to spot from the street, but when you get in, man is it worth it. They¬¥re assortment of appetizers are just great, and I greatly recommend the radish/carrot mix. I asked my waiter if I was going to survive the spicy chicken bulgogy. He told me yes, and I have to say that was not true. The food was extremely good, but I am now lacking my tactile sense in my mouth.Overall great experience.

title: Korean Restaurant in Chinatown
review: The food was very good and the staff was perfect. Love the decor - simplistic and artistic at the same time. If you do not like spicy foods, be sure to alert your waiter when placing your order. Don't miss the kimchi. We has a regular kimchi and a cucumber one that was absolutely delicious.

title: Very fine Korean cuisine in Chicago's Chinatown
review: This is a first: a Korean restaurant in Chicago's Chinatown. Located immediately to the west of the Firehouse and Moon Palace - Ahjoomah's Apron offers high level Korean cuisine. Fresh ingredients, strong flavors, real fire where it is supposed to be in the spicy dishes, and a reasonably broad menu make this a very good choice as an alternative to Chinese cuisine. This seems to me to be as good as the best Korean restaurants on North Lawrence or other Korean neighborhoods. I had a spicy stew with sausage, beef, spam (yes, spam!), vegetables and noodles, rich in flavor and all of the meats cooked just to the right degree. The restaurant is newly decorated, and very nicely so, with booths that seat 4 or 8 comfortably. Service is efficient, friendly and helpful. A real winner.

title: This place has amazing food!
review: This place has amazing food! Get the Mongolian beef.  And make sure the try the chili oil that‚Äôs on the table so spicy and so amazing! It is definitely not fancy but it is so good.

title: Decent food but do not expect friendiness!
review: This is a no frill kind of eatery with little to offer beyond that of reaosnably priced food! This reminded me of the old days when I was a yound child going to those make shift street side restaurants for a family meal in HK. Just the feel but this one is in a solid building of course! We were not welcomed or greeted with smile, thank you, or you are welcome but the food was tasty enough and that satisfied our need for bein there at this one afternoon!

title: Family wanted Chinese
review: I would give it a lower rating but my family liked it too much so I will be nice. We went walking through Chinatown and the family wanted some Chinese. I myself am not a fan of it. They chose this restaurant. I ordered BBQ ribs, I was very disappointed. They were so hard I couldn't bite them. I was only able to eat about half the pieces they gave me. They all said they loved the food but for me it is still a no go on Chinese food.

title: Not bad at all
review: Three of us came here for lunch at 12:30 a Monday afternoon. Besides one large party at a couple tables, there was nobody else dining. I thought that might not fare well for the quality of their food. I was wrong. We enjoyed our meals. Service was good. Good price. I'd come here again.

title: Poor Food
review: I came in here on accident after looking for a restaurant in the freezing cold and ordered take-out for dinner later that day. The waitress taking our order was helpful and willing to understand us in English. However, the food was downright poor. I ordered chinese broccoli and rice with soy sauce chicken. The chinese broccoli was yellow and tasted sour. For the rice and soy sauce chicken, they forgot to give me the chicken! All I got was a box full of rice and soy sauce. Instead, my friend and I had to go to a local restaurant near our apartment, as this place was too far away. I would not come here again!

title: Chinese late night
review: Needing somewhere to eat Chinese late night we gave this spot in Chinatown a try. Around 11:30pm it was quite busy and with Chinese and other Asian customers so that was a good sign. It seems they are better known for their noodles but we opted for a soup,some pot stickers and 2 orders of their steamed rice with bbq pork and fried egg. This last dish at 5.95 was a bargain. And though overall I found the food to be average the fact that it keeps late hours and is so inexpensive means I would probably return if given the chance.

title: Good wonton soup
review: We came here on a recommendation. The wonton and noodle soups are good and very flavorful but the atmosphere is not the best. The place is dirty and d√©cor is aged. Staff is not friendly and appears bothered; they do not seem to welcome or appreciate our business.

title: Welcome to the Urban Dictionary
review: I didn't know that the Urban Dictionary existed until I became acquainted with the 554 at Seven Treasures Cantonese restaurant at 2312 South Wentworth Avenue in Chicago. The 554 is listed on the menu under its official description: BBQ pork with fried eggs over rice. It's a small oval platter heaped high with fluffy, steamed white rice, smothered on one side by fatty slices of red-hued char siu (or barbecued pork) and on the other side by two fried eggs, splashed with dark soy sauce. I was informed that the code name is a holdover from the dish's number on a former menu and it was added to the Urban Dictionary by several late-night diners. What is the Urban Dictionary? It is a crowd-sourced online dictionary of slang words, cultural words and phrases that are not typically found in standard dictionaries. It was founded in 1998 as a parody of dictionary.com and vocabulary.com. When a dish makes the UD, you have to try it. Which we did. Take it from a guy who thinks Cantonese is a name for people who live in Canton, Ohio, 554 is a different but delicious and irresistible dish.

title: Very good shrimp soup
review: Don't expect much atmosphere. But the food I ordered was very good and very cheap. Reminds me of childhood restaurant when they would give you a pot of tea with water.

title: Delish!
review: This place was dirty. The floors were dirty and the bathroom was nasty but if you can get past that, you won't regret eating there. The food was soooo good! We had some sort of pork, noodle soup; the best egg rolls ever (they had peanut butter in them, weird but amazing); and shrimp fried rice.

title: A true treasure in Chinatown
review: The decor is sparse, but people who love good food aren't looking for a kitsch dining experience. The food is incredible and so cheap for the amount of joy you receive with each bite. We stumbled across this gem in Chinatown and will gladly go back every time we are in Chicago.

title: Old school restaurant
review: really want to like this place, I was hoping‚Ä¶ It been years and years since we have been here. Their food is just short of good; The stir fry beef with rice noodle dish was almost good, but some of the noodles was dry because it's been sitting out for too long, the wonton noodle soup was favorable/acceptable, but the noodle was just a tag mushy, over cooked, the beef congee was bland there was no flavor, no salt, no seasoning of any kind and the beef was rough, they should have marinate with soy sauce and corn starch. The food tasted like they don't care if it's not good enough‚Ä¶ too bad...

title: Very good food.
review: Friendly people, the service was fast, and the food delicious and it's not a expensive restaurant. The Won Ton soup was delicious. Awesomeness experience!!!!

title: Chow Fun Heaven
review: Chicago Chinatown has, in my experience, a unique prep of chow fun. In case you didn't know, chow fun is wide rice noodles, sometimes prepared in soup, dry fry or with gravy. Chicago chow fun is fried and prepared with a variety of toppings with gravy. The key is the in frying where -- and this is where "Chicago-style chow fun" excels -- the noodles are chewy, sticky and partially crispy. When the gravy topping is added -- could be fish or other meat -- the noodles just explode with flavor and eating pleasure. It all happens in the mouth as you chew and crunch the noodles. Seven Treasure, in my experience, is one of the best places for Chicago-style chow fun. They also have rice dishes and other entrees, all of which are good to very good, although for some reason, vegetables in Chicago Chinatown are expensive. Restaurant has undergone some renovation over the 30+ years I have dropped by, but it still retains a simple, understated, non-elegant atmosphere: clean baths, cab-like services (i.e., need to hail them as they pass by), and with booths removed. Best thing, they're open until 2 a.m.

title: Lunch in Chinatown
review: Ate lunch at Seven Treasures in Chinatown Chicago while visiting for a show. The service was outstanding with many items on the menu. My wife ordered the Seaweed soup and I had the Mongolian Beef. Hot Tea was complimentary with the meal. Service was excellent. Great staff. We will return again.

title: Consistently good.
review: Each time we travel to Chicago's Chinatown, we eat here.  Authentic Chinese food and service.  I love the duck, noodle dishes and Mango smoothie (just like in Toronto).  Not the cleanest place, but the food is very good.

title: Good noodles BBQ and smoothies
review: Basic noodles BBQ place with friendly staffs. We had good foods every time we go there. I'm a Chinese married a "White Cracker". So you will get both perspective. The best was the hot and sour soup, the soy sauce chicken and duck, the black bean beef chow fun. The wonton and fish ball egg noodles were good. The beef brisket was not cooked long enough and my mom's wide rice noodle in the soup was not smooth enough either. We were surprised with how good the Mango as well as the strawberry banana smoothies were. We went back the next day just for smoothies. All these foods feed 4 and stuffed for only a bit over $50. Good bargain. Would recommend of you like noodles and bbq meat.

title: Not very good.
review: We went as a party of 4. The potstickers were good everything else not so much. We tried things from the "gringo" and authentic menu . None were very good . Atmosphere is zero . There are far better choices all over Chinatown.

title: Good food, great value
review: I think this restaurant specializes and excels in noodles and wontons, although they have a full menu of regular rice dishes. My family goes elsewhere for dim sum (not available at Seven Treasures) and rice dishes. When here, we always order noodle soup, with or without the shrimp won ton dumplings. There are variations of things included in the soup -- duck, beef, liver, shrimp, etc.Good quality noodles, broth, and all the rest. A favorite.

title: Very good basic restaurant, shockingly reasonable
review: Ate here twice while staying in Chinatown for a few days. This was a basic, fundamental Chinese restaurant. No atmosphere to speak of, but great food at an amazing price. I ordered the vegetarian delight the first night, and it was excellent. Fresh veggies, sticky rice, and filled me up. Te second night, I had the braised bean curd (tofu) with veggies. Again, very tasty and good portions. The cost for each dinner was $8.30! Where else can you get good Chinese food for dinner at that price? Very extensive menu, and friendly staff. My only minor complaint was that a small piece of beef was mixed in with my second meal. If I were a hardcore vegetarian, I probably would have fled, flailing my hands and screaming, "meat is murder," but instead, I tried the beef and found it delicious too! I wouldn't take my prom date or propose to my fianc√© here, but it was tasty and inexpensive. Good enough for this traveler.

title: Great Food!
review: My husband and I visited here. It was his pick and I will admit I was a bit wary since I've never really experienced a restaurant like this. Every one was really friendly, Amazing food service..and really great portions! I was surprised at how much I got! I ordered the Chicken and Broccoli to play it safe and my husband ordered the Ox Tripe with Green Onions and Ginger. He could NOT stop raving about his meal, mine was delicious as well! This is a great place if you want somewhere quiet, inexpensive and not leave hungry!

title: Good Food, Good Prices!
review: We stumbled into this place in China Town, and we were very pleased! The prices for dinner were between $8-16 and the portion size was very big. We had the sweet and sour chicken and cashew chicken and both were delicious. There are a lot of choices in China Town, and I would definitely go back to this one.

title: Really great price and food
review: We found ourselves in Chinatown, ready to eat, so I looked up a review of Seven Treasures and decided to go there. First of all, the prices are amazing. You get a lot of food at some of the lowest restaurant prices you can imagine. I had the rice with fried egg and duck. Duck is not a cheap restaurant food in America, but it is common to the Chinese, and my meal was about $7. I couldn't hardly believe it. Keep in mind it isn't a whole duck or anything, but it was a rare treat for me. The service was excellent, the food was good for my whole family, and it is authentic Chinese. The menu is massive with choices as well. We were certainly glad we stopped at Seven Treasures.

title: Authentic Old School Cantonese
review: This is the way I remembered local Cantonese. Not Hip not Fusion or Eclectic...just good food and astounding value. Great Won Ton soup, eggrolls, egg fu young, noodles & soup....The menu has over 200 items, with most entrees under $9. I recommend exploring and ordering too much.... bring the leftovers home.Four of us had WonTon soup, egg rolls, a vegetarian dish, egg fu young, szechuan chicken, and three pork & steamed rice platters. We tried to guess what the bill was going to be. My guess was $110...it came in at $60 including tax. Even if you decide you don't like it...what is there to lose?Downside (maybe not) No liquor and I couldn't get a clear answer on BYOB.

title: Serving Cantonese noodle soup for nearly 30 years... just wish the food was better.
review: This noodle shop has been the only game in Chinatown since the '80's. The pros: authentic won ton noodle soup (I prefer beef stew or roast duck), very cheap, open late. The cons: the noodles lack the delicate snap, the soup is oily and muddy, and the restaurant hasn't been renovated since the '80's. Good when you need a noodle fix or a walk down memory lane.

title: Traditional Chinese restaurant
review: After a friend recommended that I try here for Won Ton Mein, I make it a point to visit at least once per trip when I'm in Chicago. Their Won Ton Mein comes with many options and it is a good basic, filling meal for a very, very decent price. They also have char siu, duck and other meats that one can buy by the pound at a reasonable price.I have not seen the restaurant filled with people (no dim sum), however, there is always a steady stream of customers and a decent number of large tables to host family gatherings. The resturant serves its food Chinese style (e.g. when it is cooked, it is served) and the waiters are always gracious and efficient.This is a great find.

title: Stunning Noodle Soups & Dishes
review: Although the Cantonese food here is more traditional than, say, Go 4 Food, the quality is extraordinary. The homemade noodles and broth are exquisite, and superior to any other Chicago Chinese restaurant I have tried.

title: gr8 food one of my favs...
review: gr8 food one of my favs in chicago..

title: 554 till 2 AM everyday (and it's $5!). 'Nuff said.
review: 554 till 2 AM everyday (and it's $5!). 'Nuff said.

title: good food, but i always...
review: good food, but i always have a problem with what I order

title: Great food, not amazing...
review: Great food, not amazing, but more than worth the prices and atmosphere.  It's a Chicago-area Chinatown tradition!

title: Barbeque Pork with Fried...
review: Barbeque Pork with Fried Egg over Rice for $5.50... Need I say more? Be warned the amount of calories in just one order.

title: OG is all that needs to...
review: OG is all that needs to be said

title: Won Ton Noodle Soup! 4 bucks for a bowl of noodles that are good, you can't really beat that!
review: Won Ton Noodle Soup! 4 bucks for a bowl of noodles that are good, you can't really beat that!

title: Totally disappointed!
review: I visited the restaurant 12/5. This was my favorite place to visit for food in Chinatown and I invited an old friend to this place. Unfortunately due to the change in management service is the Worse! Waitstaff could not speak and barely understood the English language. I could get over that hurdle however basic service 101 was also missing. I had a young lady that finally served our food after having a guest come to our table to interpret our order to her. Next, after we received our food, she sat down and begin eating with other staff and never returned to our table to check on us. One gentleman had finished his meal and had to loudly call out to the waitstaff that were busily eating for his check. I will never come back, perhaps they will have their service together next year!!!! The old restaurant had excellent service, this management has the worst!!! They have a full bar, but no one knew how to mix drinks!

title: Gone Down Hill under new management.
review: This used to be my favourite restaurant in Chicago's Chinatown, Since House of Fortune has changed management, however, the quality is no longer there. I gave it four chances, hoping I was just there on an off day. I find it now has poor value. The soups are watery, and the "assorted" vegetable dishes lack assortment. Their buns had little filling and in the case of their onion bun, no filling and little onion in the dough. On the last two occasions, appetizers were brought out with the meal rather than before it, and once, they were brought out only after we asked about them. They installed new tables for hotpots. These are uncomfortable; they have a shelf under them that sits so low that I had to sit sideways because my legs would not fit. Their homemade pork potstickers still very good, but even they do not have the flavour that they used to have. They have tried to replace their formerly delicious food with a trendy appearance and higher prices. I would have recommended it just a year ago. Now, after two do-overs by new management, I am no longer a fan.

title: Where is my favorite restaurant???
review: I loved this restaurant, it was definitely my go to restaurant when visiting Chinatown. Unfortunately, when I visited Chinatown yesterday the restaurant was closed!I had to eat at a different location that could not compare to the service and food in terms of excellence. I was told the House of Fortune was closed for renovations.

title: Another great lunch
review: My young daughter and I took the opportunity to have lunch at the House of Fortune today. We took advantage of the lunch special. She ordered the beef with broccoli and I enjoyed the chicken ding with cashews. The lunch special includes hot tea, soup, and crab appetizers to accompany the main dish. The servings are plentiful and we enjoyed our time there. The staff is very friendly and helpful. Our family likes to eat here as often as we can when we come into the city. We've seen them handle tour groups and large families with ease and still provide wonderful service to our table.

title: Excellent Food and Service
review: Lots of good food and good price for food. Five of us at dinner for about $70, including a 20% tip on our bill. We had some much left over after we were full that we could have eaten our dinner a second time. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!!

title: Best Orange Chicken of Your Life
review: We've been dining here with our friends for years now! The location is right at the end of the China Town strip, not as crowded. The food is AMAZING! We order 6 different dishes and appetizers. The portions are huge! They have a giant lazy Susan on the table that makes sharing a breeze. Also some great $5.50 Mai tai's!! It's unheard of to get cocktails that cheap in the city! Our average bill for 4 couples is $40- $50 with tip per couple! Then the orange chicken is seriously the best thing you will ever eat!!!! Check it out!

title: Great Value - Good Food
review: We were very impressed with the service, portion size, and value of food here. We had the Family of Three Meal, but had sweet/sour chicken and kung pao beef instead of the lobster and lemon chicken. This substitution was made easily and with no problem.The rangoons were good - a bit too much wrapper/crab, but the sauce served with them made up for it. The egg rolls were good as well, and my son loved the soup - it was also good. All three main dishes were well made, and the fried rice was some of the best I've ever had. It had lots of great veggies in it and wasn't overly greasy.The meals were fairly standard American-Chinese - which was exactly what we were looking for. Not too sweet/gloppy, and plenty of vegetables throughout.The meal came with hot tea which was delicious. I also had a whiskey sour which I considered extremely well priced, and it was well-made to boot. The whole cocktail menu was impressive price-wise.Our favorite part of our visit was the service. They quickly found us a high chair, my daughter spilled her water and it was quickly replaced, as was a fork I dropped (I didn't even need to say anything), and the server was very attentive to all our glasses and questions.I am sure there are plenty of places in Chicago with overall better food, but this was very good. If you're out of town and looking for Chinese food, you'll be happy here and so will the kids.

title: Very good food
review: First time trying house of fortune and we were very pleased. Everything we ordered was excellent   (Except the crab Rangoon). Delivery was quick.

title: Excellent Food and Atmosphere
review: Totally clean, bright and inviting dining room, absolutely delicious food and extremely economically priced.  Try the Orange Chicken and Mongolian Beef - delicious!

title: The Gem of Chinatown
review: I was told of House of Fortune many years ago from Chinese businessmen from China when I asked for a suggestion for dinner in Chinatown. I have visited dozens of times with family, friends and groups (up to 30 a few times) and have never been disappointed. Their lunch menu is a steal for under $6.00 (includes soup, crab rangoon, generous portion of your entree with regular or fried rice, tea and fortune cookie). Dinner is more but portions are bigger and more than enough to have leftovers to take home. The staff is congenial, friendly and they accommodate you for whatever you need. They will help plan out a family style dinner or lunch for 4 - 40 and leave your guests full and satisfied. A place not to miss and well worth the price you pay compared to the restaurants north of 22nd street.

title: Can't tell you about the food since they never delivered
review: Placed an order and was confirmed by email and text that deliver would be in 60-70 minutes...a long time to begin with. After more than 60 minutes we received a call saying they had made a mistake with our order and had not begun it and it would be at least another 45 minutes. Needless to say we had to cancel. 2 hours for delivery...I don't think so. We won't give them another shot...neither should you if you actually want to eat.

title: Hidden Gem
review: Set right on the Southernmost end of Chinatown on S. Wentworth, House of Fortune does not boast fancy decor, but the service is great and the food is delicious. Place was recommended to me by a colleague who ordered an excellent Peking Duck from the venue. Every table gets hot tea (I didn't have to ask on this cool Chicago day). Caught the $5.50 lunch special and had a simple chicken and broccoli. The sauce was light, the food was not heavily salted. Simply delicious food, without the pomp and circumstance.

title: We went for the Peking Duck
review: This hotel was within walking distance of the hotel we were staying in (the Chicago Loop Hotel on 26th st) and they had really good Peking duck.

title: Very poor quality food
review: We visited House of Fortune in Chicago, IL, yesterday for lunch and were extremely disappointed. The egg roll was just average, the pork potstickers were tough and barely warm and the BBQ pork bites were fatty. There are plenty of other Chinese restaurants on the same street in Chinatown and I am sure that any of them would have been better. Lastly, The restrooms were awful! The men's restroom did not even lock, neither the main door nor the stool door! We will not return.

title: Great place
review: Delicious food and friendly staff. I highly recommend the egg rolls... Yummy!!!!! It wasn't very busy I believe this is one of Chicago's hidden gems.

title: AWESOME
review: Well thesis the second time visiting this restaurant and it gets better each time some far I have tasted about 6 different dishes and every one has been superb.

title: Family Dinner for 3 came with plenty of food to share!
review: We were in Chicago for the day and decided to go to China Town for lunch. There are so many restaurants to choose from, we chose the closest one to where we parked the car. We made an excellent choice with House of Fortune.We ordered the Family Dinner for 3. The soup of the day was a traditional Egg Drop soup that came out very hot and fast.The Spring Roll came out crunchy on the outside yet moist and delicious on the inside, along with Crab Rangoon which had enough crab to taste and was very slightly sweet. These were served with a small dish of duck sauce and a small dish of hot mustard.The Lemon Chicken was cooked just right and was extremely good and zesty; very sweet and very good. The Beef with Vegetable had large pieces of freshly cooked vegetables and came in a slightly pungent brown sauce which as terrific. We substituted the Shrimp with Lobster Sauce with Spicy Pork and we were not disappointed. We were quite happy that they allowed the substitution to the Family Dinner without any disagreement.The staff was very attentive, the prices are reasonable, and the food is great. They have a full bar and the drinks are also reasonably priced. They are the first Chinese restaurant that I have found that serves Lychee Wine by the glass.

title: House of Furtune - a great Dim Sum place
review: Hidden from the eye Dim-Sum restaurant in Chicago's china town. I came on 9:00 AM when the restaurant was still empty, the service was great, the food was genuine, fresh and delicious, and the prices on the floor.Deeply recomended. Notice that at noon there is a queue of 20-30 min for tables...

title: Dinner for 4 enough for 6
review: Don't let impression of decor influence your dining experience to come. It's clean and basic but the food is anything but!Nice selection of drinks available and menu to match.Peking duck is wonderful and rolled into Pancakes efficiently. The mixed vegetables are some of the best I've had. Mongolian beef & shrimp with oyster sauce very good.The owner/manager takes pride in his establishment for good reasons.Next time in chicago, will order pea pod greens as platters went by us after we ordered looked fabulous.Worth the drive from downtown.Many repeat customers...no wonder!

title: It's OK
review: I see there are some rave reviews about this place. About all I can say is, it's OK. Staff is pleasant and polite. The food we had was nothing special. Spicy Szechuan chicken and Tenderloin Beef in Hot Pepper Sauce. My brother-in-law had the chicken. Nothing to rave about. It was fine (spicy too!). The beef I had was the most non-tender tenderloin I've ever had. It was tasty enough and prices were great, but, again, nothing to write home about. I can only give this place a solid 3-star, average rating.

title: Very good restaurant in Chinatown
review: Very pleasant waiter and manager. Quiet atmosphere. Reasonably priced and tasty food! Big portions. I really loved the Egg tofu and mushrooms dish, the dumplings and the mustard sauce. This place doesn't look awesome from the outside but I can tell you that it really is.

title: Enjoyed !!!!
review: Just remember when you walk in, it's not for the ambiance. We had several entrees and shared all of them. The Combination fried rice was one of the best I have had. Most of the dishes were good. The portions were VERY generous. Overall I enjoyed it and would go back. I hope they improve their wine list though! It's not fine dining but you will not go away hungry.

title: ho-hum Chinese compared to other big cities
review: For being a top-ranked Chinese restaurant in Chicago, we were pretty disappointed. We had some dim sum, some vegetarian, some fish, and some sweet-n-sour. Nothing was really great compared to the better restaurants in other big cities in the world (not to mention Hong Kong). The price was reasonable though and maybe my expectations were a little high.

title: Great Food
review: This is the 1st time I ate at this Chinese- Cantonese restaurant. The outside is not as spectacular but the food that was served was really good & huge portions. It was different from other Chinese restaurants I have tried. The server was pleasant & manager/ owner was around and checking on the customers, which I felt was a touch of personalized service. Although I would say parking around the area is hard to find. Over all experience was great .

title: GREAT FOOD AND SERVICE
review: Well read the review on trip advisor and decided to give this place a try. I had the "mashed chicken and corn soup", just flavorful and enough for two. For appetizers we had the potstickers never have had just great homemade ones, my partner had the scallions pancakes just great taste and flavor. For main entree I had the salt and spicy pork chops WOW what flavor and just the right amount of spice too. My partner had the beef and onions and that was just great the beef was just so tender you could cut it with the fork. The sauce and just right and not greasy at all. The server was just great and explained all the dishes and all the questions we had too. To top it off had a great almond cookies with the usual fortune cookie.

title: Good food good value
review: Went here based on the previous reviews. Ate the lunch special - only $5.50 and comes with soup, crab rangoon, rice and entree - what a deal. The food was good along with the portion. Service was very good. We will return on our next visit to Chinatown.

title: Great place, first time in Chinatown. Great food.
review: We came here after a review we read on tripadvisor. It was spot on. Great service. Very yummy food. We had crab Rangoon, chinese broccoli, chicken corn soup and sweet and sour chickenThey were all really good. The owners came around a couple times and were really friendly. Definitely will be back

title: Everything was Perfect
review: Stopped by for a business lunch.They must have read my mind--the kung pao chicken was spiced perfectly hot and was full of tender chunks on white meat chicken. The authentic fish with mushrooms was very fresh and delicately spiced. The service was friendly and prompt. The price was very reasonable. If I lived in Chicago, I'd go there all the time. The best meal I had all week. Fantastic!

title: Can't wait to go back. Duck is a must.
review: Drove 40 minutes in the rain to get here and it did not disappoint. You must order the Peking duck. It's amazing. All the food was delicious and the service was impeccable. Can't wait to get back. Oh yeah, when you get the bill, you will be pleasantly surprised. Enjoy.

title: Best Chinese vegetarian dish in Chinatown
review: I have been coming to Chinatown every chance I get after a long day of tradeshow at McCormick place. The people are friendly, knows the dishes, and they even created a delicious mix of two vegetarian favorates to satisfy my craving. I'm glad to find an alternate to the regular busy joints we frequent, where the atmosphere is cozy and food is delicious.

title: The Best Chinese Restaurant in Chicago!!!
review: We have been going to House of Fortune for years and it is always a great experience!! Great food, low prices and nice people. We have many friends who we have introduced this restaurant to who call it one of their family favorites, now. It is far cheaper than the $30 per person quoted in the summary. Just last night we went there for my husband's birthday and had won ton soup for all 7 of us (all adults), eggrolls, crab rangoon, 2 orders of the best chicken fried rice in my son's universe, Mongolian beef, 2 orders of kung pao chicken, walnut shrimp, steamed vegetables, orange chicken, General Tso's chicken and white rice all for the low price of $130.00. We really over ordered and everyone took home leftovers for 7 more entire meals! If you are looking for a genuine Chinese restaurant, this is it! The one thing it does lack is a flashy decor, but can you eat decor???? The ambiance that this restaurant lacks is more than made up for in a stroll down the streets of Chinatown as you stop in the gift shops and bakeries.

title: Never disappointed.
review: Never disappointed.

title: Delicious!
review: If you are in Chinatown, or even if you aren't, be sure and check this place out!  Delicious authentic Chinese food!  Biggest oyster I've ever had!  All of the dishes we tried were excellent.

title: Best seafood over the last couple of years
review: My brother, a decades long resident of Chicago, held his birthday dinner party here for about 20 people (incidentally, all three races were represented). My wife and I agreed that it was the best seafood we had had over the last couple of years (we...live in California by the sea and we travel extensively, trips to Asia and Europe every year). The only negative is the rather tight seating, as might be expected in a reasonably priced Chinatown restaurant. Highly recommended for the quality of the food.More

title: Great Food / Service
review: Great food, great portions, great service. I took my Mother, 2 Sisters and a Niece. We all shared what we ordered on a large lazy susan. The table next to us ordered a huge live $450.00 crab. quite a show an experience that left quite...a memory!More

title: Glad we tried something new in Chinatown. Loved the shrimp and scallops with veggies. subtle hint of lemongrass ..yum!
review: Glad we tried this place. So fresh and delicious! We will be back!!!i loved the shrimp and scallops with veggies. The hint of lemongrass was perfect.More

title: Birthday supper!
review: Great service, great food.  The sci fi movies were pretty distracting for kids...  You had to remind them to eat!  Very enjoyable evening.  Delicious, authentic, generous dishes.More

title: Great food, not great service
review: Four of us went here for lunch.  We all ordered at the same time. Two of our meals came out right away, the other two came out 20 minutes later.  We asked 3 times, 3 different people, about the missing meals, just to be told...they would be ready in another minute.  (I believe one person we asked was a manager, because he was not dressed in black, like the servers were.) The food was delicious, but because of the poor service, we will not return.More

title: great food
review: This is the real deal when it comes to Chinese seafood. I have no idea where they even buy half of their food. Very Good !!!

title: Another very good Cantonese kitchen
review: Wentworth Seafood is one of the better Cantonese restaurants in Chicago‚Äôs Chinatown. The obvious emphasis is on seafood, and the clams in Black Bean Sauce were exquisite, as were the fillets of fish in a casserole with tofu. Beef chow fun was good but a...bit too salty. Shrimp with Chinese yams another highlight. Overall a very good and not Americanized Restaurant. Prices very reasonable and good service.More

title: Lovely Chinese Food
review: We were looking for Chinese food and went to Chinatown. After walking down the main street and looking at all the restaurants, this one was full of local Chinese people and the dishes looked great, so we went in. Amazing food! Hot pockets as a...starter was delicious! And then $15 dishes which you can't eat by yourself. We ordered 2 main dishes and barely touched the second one. Very good Chinese food.More

title: Not a good choice for food allergies
review: WARNING: NOT a good choice for egg allergies!  The purpose of this review is to alert those with food allergies. I came here based on Yelp reviews, but none mentioned anything about allergens. I'm here to rectify that point.  If you happen to have an...egg-allergy, this is NOT the place for you. I have a combination egg and orange allergy so my food options were severely limited. While the staff is more than willing to answer questions, that was not the problem, most meats are coated in egg/egg whites. I understand this is a method for velveting meats, but so is cornstarch. While I was not impressed (as there were so few choices for me) my friend, who has no allergies, said the food was very good.   So, to recap: no allergies--go for it! Allergies--stay away.More

title: Exceptional Chinese food
review: Tried this place a few days ago. Their big crab was amazing and the steamed fish was also too die for. We ordered the clay pot with sea cucumber and beef tendon which was very good. Lastly, the bean tips with broth were fresh and...More

title: AWFUL DON'T EAT HERE
review: I've been eating out for many years and this is the very first time there's a bug in my food. I'm pretty sure it's a cockroach.   Won't be coming back.

title: YEAR OF DISAPPOINTMENT
review: Was there on New Years Eve with my brother, friends had told us how good the food was.  We got there about 5:30 and restraurant was pretty empty.  We were seated right away but went down hill from there.  Lets just say service was non...existent.  We started with order of crab rangoon, which was very good.  We both ordered soup and had to ask waitress 2 times, Where is our soup?  She replied both times, Its coming, well we waited close to 25 mins before soup came.  OK both soups were great when they finally made it to our table.  We needed a few extra napkins and again asked waitress if she could bring a couple more, never got them.  Finally took order for dinner,, so I have to say the food was good but wait staff is non attentive and its not like the place was busy, I think there was a total of 5 tables that were filled, thats it. I dont know if we would go back just due to the lack of service, but did enjoy the food..More

title: Real chinese food
review: I love real chinese food; so we choose this restaurant because was the most far away in Chinatown (away from tourist), and also because have szechuan food. We tried szechuan style shrimp, mapo tofu and some szechuan raviolis. Everything was perfect, flavor, spices and textures....Personal very kindly and friendly.More
