title: the food is good, but kitchen does not know it is suppose to run like a restaurant
review: The food is very good here. Just avoid this place when the dining room is more than 50% full, because the kitchen does not know how to push out orders like a restaurant. We waited over an hour for the food to arrive, the only...reason the food showed up was we told them we were going to walk out. The wait staff does not know how to lie to customers, at least go into the kitchen & check before coming back & telling to customers the kitchen is trying to get your order out.The wait staff needs to keep their remarks to themselves, never let a customer hear you say if you do not like it leave. No restaurant needs wait staff personnel with that type of attitude.More

title: Quite good Chinese food!
review: I ordered takeaway. I aet their Mongolian Beef and it was quite good. Big serving, you wont leave hungry! Delivery was quite fast

title: Good fresh Chinese food
review: Stayed in Chinatown four nights and decided on this place on my last night. Best of the 4 Chinese restaurants I tried. Had a mixed seafood dish which was great intaste and plenty of it. Service was good and the place was tidy. Happy I...tried it.More

title: Pretty Decent!
review: Once in a while when my wife and I visit Chicago, we meet friends here at The Evergreen in Chinatown. The service is always good. The food on the other hand can go either way. Unfortunately there is no consistency. We all ordered different things...and shared. There was plenty of food for the price and as any Chinese Restaurant there were leftovers to take home.More

title: Reasonable Cost for What You Get
review: We went here for a quick snack and drink because it was the closest to where we were at the time. Service was fast and friendly. Had shrimp egg rolls which were good, but I've had better. Tea was excellent. Won ton soup was good...and a very large portion. Pina Colada - very good. Atmosphere ok. Had a TV on with the news and a large group of male senior patrons were very loud. Reasonable prices. Don't go out of your way to go here.More

title: My second choice due to closing of first choice.
review: This restaurant was my second choice because The House of Fortunate was closed.  Service was good and the food was fair.

title: Average traditional Chinese-American restaurant
review: I had dinner here during prime-time on a holiday weekend, and it was very crowded. They do have many large round tables that seat 8-12, so if you're a group, this is the place for you.  The food was average, but maybe I should have...been more adventurous in ordering. Hot & Sour soup was oddly thick and dark, but neither very hot nor sour. Shrimp and Scallops Hong Kong Style was okay, but not special.. Pot of tea was good. Service adequate, but the bustle of people constantly walking around my table and crowding me made my meal unpleasant. I don't think I'd go here again--I'd get the same quality and experience for half the price at a chain Chinese Fast Food.More

title: Never go back
review: Fourteen years ago I visited this restaurant. My memories of that visit was very strong in that the experience was a positive way. So back in Chicago I decided to revisit a past memory. I should not have done so. Whilst the food wasn't bad...More

title: Good tasty authentic Chinese food
review: We had a amazing meal for 30 of us.  Unfortunately it was after a funeral.  We had lobster, crispy skin chicken, seafood plater with with book choy, fresh halibut fish, bbq pork, kei lan and cream corn soup.   The negative is trying to find parking....More

title: Good Food, Good Location for Chinese New Year Parade
review: This was my first Chinese New Year parade. I met some acquaintances at the restaurant before the parade began.  The food is traditional Cantonese. The menu is extensive with plenty of selections including vegetarian. I ordered egg rolls (with meat,) Shrimp and BBQ Pork with...More

title: Nice oriental restaurant
review: While visiting Chicago, we went to Chinatown specifically to eat oriental food.  We walked to the end of Wentworth Ave in the Chinatown area and decided to eat here.  The portions were huge and very good.

title: One of the Best Restaurants in Chinatown
review: I have visited several restaurants in Chinatown, but I've settled on Evergreen as my favorite. The large majority of the patrons are from the surrounding Chinatown neighborhood, which confirms the restaurant's authenticity. The prices are reasonable. Sometimes we've had to wait for a table due...More

title: As authentic Chinese as can be
review: As a group of five, we wandered into the restaurant near the end of the immediate Wentworth area for dinner. It was a pleasant surprise. Not being native Chinese speakers, the waitress was very helpful in choosing for us what we could only describe.The food...More

title: Decent Chinese food but there is better
review: We purchased a Groupon for Evergreen so the price was great for what we got but as Chinese food goes, it was just average. Service was very good and the portions are HUGE so that was nice.

title: Quite a Good Lunch
review: Four of us went to Chinatown to shop and decided to go to this restaurant for lunch. Plenty of very good food at inexpensive prices. No need for an entree; I got soup and an appetizer and had more than I could eat. Many locals...More

title: Chinatown restaurant frequented by neighborhood residents
review: There were five of us, and I wish we had had a larger group because the more people you have, the more dishes you get to try.  We were all seafood lovers, and we were thrilled to know that they had live lobsters and fresh...More

title: So good
review: We ordered the salt and pepper shrimp (SO FLAVORFUL, and huge), green beans (perfectly prepared) and the prime rib (tender, juicy and flavorful). We also ordered pina coladas, which were excellent. Everything was stunningly good. And the prices were even better. Serving sizes are huge-...More

title: Whateverüëé
review: Not an evening to remember. We were eight of us for dinner. Firstly the waitress wasn't helpful/friendly at all. We ordered four dishes and she rudely said ..."That's it ?" . And after she gets our nod she responds with a "whatever". Our three dishes..the...More

title: Great Service and Delicious Food
review: We had a party of 11 with no reservation and we were seated quickly.  Our server helped us choose several dishes to satisfy our many likes and dislikes.  We split several dishes and enjoyed every one.  Egg rolls were good but not great, hot and...More

title: A-mazing place! BEST General tso's I have had!
review: I had to take a friend to the airport and have always stopped in China town if I am in Chicago.. when lunch time came the restaurant I have always stopped at is now gone :-( so I decided to give this one a try.....More

title: Very friendly and frequented by locals
review: This is a family restaurant that on our visit was full of families and their somewhat rowdy children.  Our greeter was very friendly, and we were well taken care of.  The hot and sour soups were large and delicious.  The "sour" part of "hot and...More

title: Don't miss this restaurant!
review: We had a group of 52 seniors and Evergreen served us a delicious feast!  We had five different entrees as well as appetizers, soup and desserts.  The service was excellent and Miss Bing, was attentive to our needs and sent us away with a bag...More

title: Large Menue all good, all inexpensive.
review: Have had several meals here.  All have been very good.  Recently had Peking Duck, outstanding.  Two people filled & satisfied. $30.00 w/tea.

title: Very fine Cantonese in Chicago's Chinatown
review: This is a very fine Cantonese kitchen in Chicago's Chinatown. What distinguishes it from the ordinary is that the ingredients are consistently fresh, the sauces are delicate and varied, rather than thick. Many Cantonese restaurants have what my wife and I call "UBS" - Ubiquitous...More

title: Authentic Value
review: Order from the Chinese menu. Get the family dinner for 6, mostly seafood items. Walk away for under $100 tax included.

title: very good Chinese "American-friendly" food in Chinatown
review: We enjoyed a very nice Christmas lunch here with my in-laws, who are Taiwanese and come here frequently with both American & East Asian friends. The restaurant was full with an even split between Asian & Caucasian customers and many "mixed" parties (including ours since...More

title: Lovely Chinese restaurant
review: We were in China Town and decided to stay for dinner. Evergreen Restaurant has a huge menu with many wonderful selections. The portions are very generous, the pricing is reasonable and the food was delicious. Our server was wonderful- friendly and very helpful. The restaurant...More

title: Some very tasty dishes here: crispy chicken, szechuan eggplant, green beans. A good place for groups- they have nice...
review: Some very tasty dishes here: crispy chicken, szechuan eggplant, green beans. A good place for groups- they have nice round tables that are perfect for family style.

title: The worst Dining experience ever
review: I agree with the rating below. The staff are rude and the place is highly overrated.  One of our dishes came in just before we were ready to leave and the whole time, our waitress ignored us. So, I told her that she could take...More

title: Bitter Aftertaste
review: I took my family to this restaurant after much recommendation. I was terribly disappointed. The server was extremely rude to us. We tried to call her to inquire after our order (Since half our order hadn't arrived 40 minutes. after we started eating). She pretended...More

title: Great value
review: Lunch for four less than $40. Dim sum was great with authentic options and the kids were able to get sweet and sour type dishes. Service was decent. Only complaint would be that the bathroom wasn‚Äôt very well kept.

title: Good Food, Fair Price, Interesting Ambiance
review: We were hungry.  We saw a parking spot.  It was raining.  We parked and went in.  They have carryout and table service.  We ate at a table.  The TV is tuned to Chinese Language shows but the sound is off and there are Chinese subtitles....Each table has chopsticks, napkins and a small plate at each place.  Tea came immediately without asking.  The menu is broad with pork, seafood, beef, chicken, soups and a few appetizers.  Service was good and friendly though limited English.  The food was very good.  The prices were OK.  $12.81 + tax + tip got us, in addition to the tea, 2 egg rolls and an orange chicken dinner with broccoli and rice that was enough for the two of us to split.More

title: Less seasonies, Hold the Pepper Please!
review: I attended a convention in the Windy City August 2018 and stayed in China Town because of its location to  Mccormick Convention Center and the fabulous Chinese restaurants in the area...I ate every day for four days at a different restaurant finding out they use...way to much seasoning,salt,pepper etc.. The China Cafe and another cafe have a beef bullion type soup that is excellent for a midwestern person like myself and the China Cafe at my request held back"?" on the extra herbs,large bowl,one size, perfect;meat was tender,easy to chew, soup or liquid very tasty and large glass of water just in case....This cafe had more local customers then visitors like myself but I could understand the waiter very well and this was a sit down and eat place not a buffet style cafeMore

title: Great chinese food with good service in nice atmosphere
review: I was here for a snack around lunch and enjoyed the BBQ duck and green tea. The staff was very friendly and efficient. The taste was excellent and the prices were low.  I recommend this place for a nice lunch or dinner at fair prices....The restaurant looked modern and clean and much nicer than many places I saw before in a Chinatown.More

title: Authentic, good value
review: Clean, fresh, good variety of dim sum and small dishes. Another 10 big special dishes are posted on the wall: lobster, fish, etc.  Hong Kong soap operas play continuous on the TV. Steamed and baked buns were very good. Service is uneven, 2 were very...nice but the seating hostess was stern - her focus was on  making sure we closed the door so that we would not let in the winter wind.More

title: New Owners -  Traditional Cantonese Food
review: We stop into this Chinatown restaurant after wondering through the area. We enjoy most of the items we picked to eat, ordered Sizzling Beef, Chicken Hot Pot and the West Lake Beef Soup.  Best item and highly recommended would be the Sizzling Beef, the Chicken...Hot Pot was a bit over cooked and no flavor. The Sizzling Beef came very hot and it comes with Pepper and Onions. The Chicken Hot Pot was a bit overcook and the chicken comes with bones with mushrooms and garlic, my husband said the mushrooms were delicious. We always order West Lake Beef Soup, it's not a traditional broth soup, it is a clear broth with pork, egg whites, cilantro but this restaurant added chopped mushrooms. If it wasn't for the mushrooms I would have like it better but it was used as a filler, not much pork or cilantro. It was perfect for my husband who loves mushrooms.  Normally the soup comes to the table first but for some reason it kept being forgotten by the staff, we were compensated for the lack it did not arrive to the table in a timely manner.  We found out the the new owners opened this restaurant three months ago, it is very clean and nice decor. I would recommend this place if you like Cantonese food.More

title: A la carte dim sum available
review: Cozy little restaurant with average service and food. Had better and worse. Prices average. Given the other choices available, I'd try my luck and palate at other places.

title: Disappointed Dim Sum
review: This place used to be under a different name. The place went thru some renovations, but I can't say the food or service has improved. We ordered turnip cake, shrimp crepe, shrimp stuffed peppers, fried rice roll, and fried taro roll. Selling dim sum should...be a very competitive business in Chinatown, but none of the dishes stand out. The floor was sticky, and washroom sink was not working. We will not be back.More

title: Wow they sure have really good food at a great price
review: Found this restaurant by walking in Chinatown in Chicago.  Used trip advisor to help us figure out which of the highly recommended restaurants to select.  This had received good reviews and we were not disappointed.  We had chicken fried rice (perfectly cooked), Mongolian chicken, and...Kung pao chicken.  Food was excellent and the bubble Thai tea was great.More

title: I can't eat all my dumplingsüò≠üò≠üò≠
review: This was a great out of the way not really known place that locals and tourists eat at alike. This was an explosion of true authentic Cantonese Cuisine. With Dim Sum and a menu that reads like a trip to the Orient. Key word is...patience, you may have to wait, they may seem to forget you are there. Be nice, polite and just be prepared for some of the freshest and most delicious food you have ever had. My wife and I went there because it looked nice (and it was close to where we parked) and we have found our home. When we come back to Chicago this will be one of our first stops..and probably our last too. Please go and enjoy.üòâMore

title: Busting Bubble tea
review: I was craving a bubble tea while walking through China Town and stopped into china Cafe. They offered a different twist - popping bubbles! So I got a strawberry "tea"($3.25) with mango bursts(+$0.75). Instead of tapioca balls, there are little beads filled with mango juice...More

title: Quick one time stop
review: We ordered the chicken fried rice, egg roll, crab ragoons, and egg drop soup to go from here. All were really good! The chicken fried rice is a large serving for only 7.99 and we had it as leftovers for the next couple days and...More

title: Authentic Chinese Food
review: We sat near the door and the kitchen and it was fun to see the different trays of food come out. The food was yummy and authentic and reasonably priced. The wait staff was excellent. It was definitely not "Americanized", this was the real stuff.

title: Good authentic Chinese food, pleasant time
review: Had a few hours downtime in Chicago this weekend, so my wife and I visited Chinatown. Enjoyed a parade and many happy faces along the streets. Asked a few locals for a favorite place to eat and settled in at China Cafe for a nice...More

title: Eat where the locals do!
review: Nice little place for authentic dim sum lunch.  We visit every few months from Northern Illinois.  We are a Cantonese family, and this food tastes like home.  Big draw for us - it's mainly locals.  We enjoy the dim sum, not a super large assortment,...More

title: Great Box lunches
review: This place may look like a dive, but if you are looking for a ‚Äúbox lunch‚Äù which consists of a meal of your choice over rice, then this is the place to go.  You can order almost anything over rice at a box lunch price...More

title: Very busy on Sunday mornings; dim sum was good.
review: Went to china cafe on Sunday morning for dim sum and this place was packed. It looked like china cafe only have one push cart for the dim sums. Many offerins were carried in a tray by the wait staff from table to table. May...More

title: Disgusting!
review: Pork was incredibly fatty, bamboo wrapped shredded pork was greasy. Barbecue pork buns and shrimp dumplings were passable. Go somewhere else!

title: Good Cantonese in Chicago's Chinatown
review: China Cafe is a fine restaurant with a large, varied menu mostly of Cantonese cuisine. There are a few Sichuan dishes but I haven't tried them.  In addition to the standard fare, there are some good dishes slightly off the beaten path. We had a...More

title: Just OK Food
review: First, we realize that authentic Chinese food is a lot different from the American version.  However, the Egg Rolls were just plain "not good".  My husband's duck was OK.  He wanted a cup of Hot and Sour Soup but was told they only sell bowls...not cups.  He ordered it because he wanted some but only ate a 1/3.  My Pork Chow Fun lacked "flavor" and was a big disappointment.  We would never go back.More

title: Great Wall Chinatown
review: A family run business tucked in the Chinatown Square area.  Best for hanging Chinese BBQ meats and quick rice dishes.  We ordered the soy chicken and roast pork and it was tasty and filling, and at a low price.  Friendly staff, the place has a...homey feel to it with the old furnishings.More

title: English language not required
review: Fantastic duck!  Just need to remember to order American style (hot) and not Chinese style (cold). Great service from a middle age lady who did a fantastic job communicating with us with hand gestures without speaking much English. She gets my vote for the best...waitress of 2017.  Give this restaurant a try and explore the menu for something new to try.More

title: First rate Cantonese
review: This is just like a good quality neighborhood joint in Hong Kong or Guangzhou. Not fancy in any way, but really good Cantonese food. The house Pork soup was really rich in flavor. The cuttlefish and roast pork over rice was wonderful. The pork skin...was firm and crackling, the meat tender. The beef chow fun was also excellent with good quality beef cooked just right.   Ambience is not to be looked for. They were mopping the floor as we ate, a TV set runs all the time. Service is warm and efficient but English is not strong. That underlines the authenticity. We loved it and will be back.More

title: Chinatown
review: Hole in the wall place  Overall good experience.  Huge egg rolls  Food is freshly made and lots of it!  Easy to find as close to train station

title: A Not So Big Surprise
review: My wife and I were in Chicago for business. I had been to Chinatown before. The restaurant we had planned on visiting wasn't open, so we stopped when we saw the roast meat in the window. We sat down at a table. A matron came...up and showed us the menus. We chose the house specialty noodle soup. We were both pleased with our meal. Then the matron brought us another dish to try. We hadn't ordered it, but apparently she thought we appreciated real Cantonese food. It was great too. Better yet, it was very reasonably priced.More

title: Good Cantonese restaurant
review: This is clearly a Cantonese kitchen, and a good one. The Sichuan dishes should probably be avoided -- too much sauce, not really spicy enough, nowhere near authentic.  But the Cantonese dishes explain why the majority of customers here are Chinese.  Service is very friendly...- though English is a bit limited. The Beef and Chinese Broccoli Cantonese fried noodles were excellent, with a delicate and very interesting sauce.  The Hot and Sour soup was quite good as well (surprisingly well balanced and spicy enough).  There are many Cantonese choices on the menu and the prices are very low.  BBQ pork is another good specialty.More

title: Best BBQ pork in Chicago- just like Hong Kong!
review: We will normally would never go into a hole in the wall like this in Chinatown. But we won a gift certificate an an event, so we went.  The workers are no non-sesnse (means a little rude) but let that go and enjoy the real...cheap food of Hong Kong at this little restaurant. Yes, we actually goes to Asia every other year or so to eat and HK is on our list.More

title: Cheap and good food, but don't eat in!
review: I've been going here for about 10 years now, and the food is very good.  Definitely go for the lunch specials as some of them are the same as dinners but half the price.  If you eat in, expect subpar to horrible service.  I would...just do take out.More

title: A Hole in the Wall Serving Great Food
review: Best soy sauce chicken, princess chicken, and BBQ ribs in Chinatown!  Get there early since they often run out by noon.

title: Great Takeaway barbecue pork and duck
review: One of the best barbecue duck and pork places in China town.  Don;t bother eating there.  It is a a real dive.  But if you want take out, particularly of those two items, it can't be beat and is a reasonable price.

title: Good, Cheap (has seen better times)
review: I used to go here back in the '90's... a lot. It was very reasonably priced (for university students), the portions were solid and the taste was mostly good. If you splurged for the set meals, you could get a nice selection of courses plus...More

title: Cheap and good
review: On a recent visit to Chicago, decided to explore their Chinatown.  Most restaurants were empty or closed. The Great Wall had patrons so we decided to give it a try.  Had the fish filet and vegetables rice plate. Very tasty.  My husband ordered a wonton...More

title: Great foods!
review: Do not expect good or great service. Have been there for 15+ yrs. Great BBQ with limited quantity.  Roast pork Belly rib sell out quickly. Roasted duck and others are also popular. "Pretend as you are in a street foods market." Walked by, look, point,...More

title: Great Breakfast
review: Ordered  beef and broccoli for breakfast.  The portions were large.  My friend and I should have ordered one.  Soup came as a starter.  Service was quick and friendly.  Prices were reasonable.   I really wanted to try the roast duck that was hanging up in the...More

title: Authentic! Great chinese Roast Duck
review: Fast service great food in the heart of china town Chicago; Reminds us of our favorite Chinese restaurant in Guangdong China;  Love their Roast Pork, Chicken, and Duck!  huge portions! very reasonably priced especially for Chicago! we love traveling 3 hours to come and eat...More

title: More for less
review: A good friend and I decided to meet in Chinatown for dinner. My favorite in Chicago's Chinatown, the Chiam, has been long gone. A while ago we ate at one that used so much msg that my daughter's hands swelled up. By chance we stopped...More

title: Christmas Lunch outing
review: Very affordable and the food was ok. The staff was not helpful in understanding the ordering process and not as helpful as I would have hoped.   I‚Äôm not sure I would go  back since there are other options in Chinatown.

title: Delicious and friendly.
review: We were over from London where there are several really decent Sichuan restaurants so we sought out one in Chicago and were recommended this one. It was fantastic, delicious food and well worth the trip to Chinatown. We really loved the dry tofu appetizer which...was particularly delicious. I had the salt chicken which was delicious as was the dry beef with chili. One thing that really stood out was the service. Lovely waiter and I even got to meet her mum. We got some complimentary sweet rice balls at the end of the meal. Highly recommended and we will will be back when we're in Chicago next. Thanks!!More

title: We felt like we were in a much more expensive restaurant
review: A group of 6 went to dinner, we had a large round table with a lazy Susan so we could share the food. My husband ordered for everyone, our favorite was a fish dish with a crispy coating and a spicy lamb dish. They brought...one or two dishes at a time so everything stayed hot. The only issue is that they didn't give us wine glasses so we used our tea cups. It's BYOB!More

title: Adequate at best
review: I had high hopes after reading the other reviews, but my experience was okay at best.  I stopped in for a late lunch after 1:15 and was the only customer.  The server took my order and brought it fairly quickly then disappeared.  I had to...go looking for her to get a check.  No refill on water and no tea offered.  I ordered double-cooked pork which was thinly sliced salted pork, but overly fatty.  It was served with snap peas, cabbage, jalapeno and green onion.  The dish was oily and did not get better therefore as it cooled.More

title: Excellent and Authentic Sichuan Restaurant
review: We walked to Chinatown from McCormack Place Convention center and we were looking for a restaurant my son had greatly enjoyed the previous year. We could not find it and ventured into Yan Bang Cai only to realize this was what we were looking for...with Salt Miner's dishes. I lived in Beijing for 3 years and traveled through much of China. Since we returned to Maine we have not found anything that reminded us of the great restaurants we frequented in China. Yan Bang Cai is very authentic and the dishes easily compare to excellent Sichuan restaurants in China. We shared the scallion cakes, Salt Miner's eggplant, and Salt Miner's chicken and they were all excellent. I would highly recommend this restaurant as a destination or as a 25 minute walk from the convention center.More

title: Great Authentic food
review: One of the best in Chicago. Delicious, authentic and unaltered to fit American preference which is rare to find.

title: Great Szechuan food
review: Tried this small non-descript restaurant in Chinatown on recommendation of a friend who is a Chinese food expert...he is right..food is terrific, authentic Szechuan. We tried a variety of dishes, from noodles, to soup, to ho..and others. All were well prepared, tasty, authentic. Don't miss...t.More

title: Another great Sichuan restaurant in Chicago
review: Chicago has a few really fine Sichuan restaurants, and this is another of them - with some dishes not found elsewhere. The spice level is authentically hot (they will make it milder if you request), the ingredients are very fresh, and the menu is extremely...creative and inventive.  Very much worth a visit.More

title: Authentic Sichuanese food, good stop
review: Going on a China town trip with my college class with a guide from the actual Sichuan province, I would say faith in her opinion that this is authentic Sichuan food is well placed. If you like spicy food this is the place for you....For those not accustomed to actual Chinese food (not the American Chinese food) this place will be an eye opener for you. If your not into the spicy food they serve a wide variety of foods from around China.   My suggestion for a visit, go with a group and order the dishes for the group and share them around one of the round tables with a spinning center. This is how they eat many of their meals in China. It may help, though not a must, to have someone familiar with the dishes since the accent can be tough to get through at times and there is a HUGE amount of dishes. Imagine if Mexican, American, Italian, and German food was all served at the same restaurant and you'll get an idea of what the variety of dishes is.More

title: Reminds me of NYC Chinatown - But it's BYO
review: I've found that so many of the Chinese restaurants in Chicago area feature such sweet sauces in their dishes, but Yan Bang Cai reminds me of the East Coast places where I was first introduced to great Chinese food.  The sauces are savory and spicy...- not sweet.  From the Chinese menu we enjoyed Twice Cooked Pork, billed as Deng Xiaoping's favorite food from his visit to Sichuan Provincial Capital, Zigong.   My wife had shrimp with Ginger and Scallions, also from Chinese Menu.  It was a cold night, so my son ordered Steamed Dumpling Soup from Chinese Menu, but was disappointed when the waiter brought only dumplings and sauce - explaining that the chef decided this was not a soup.  I am taking off a star for the waiter not telling us up-front.  My son also tried the Chinese canned beverage translated as Fruity Jelly Drink, which was sort of grape-colored with clear chewy bits which flowed into your mouth through the straw.  Also enjoyed fried dumplings (pot-stickers) which were the best I've had.  The fried wontons were only so-so.  Give this place a try.  They will validate parking stubs for the big lot below the L train.More

title: Excellent!!
review: Boys night out and had an outstanding dinner - I would recommend the following:  cold noodle appetizer (don't get the beef), hot and sour soup, garlic and salt prawns, lamb and sweet potato dish (yes - you heard it - it was great - very...More

title: Truly authentic Sichuanese food - best in Chinatown
review: Situated between the Old and the New Chinatown squares (across from the historic Chinatown gate and near the fire department), this place offers a rare opportunity to enjoy great food in a relaxing environment (unlike others that try to be buzz worthy). As someone who...More

title: Very good
review: We were looking for a Szechuan restaurant.  The Lao Szechuan had bad reviews from Asians, so we decided not to go there.  This place was empty at 1pm on a Sunday, so we really hesitated at first.  The lady was very friendly and helpful.  The...More

title: Stunning Sichuan addition to Chicago's Chinatown
review: The correct name is Yan Bang Cai (at least in our alphabet), and it is in the location of the now defunct Double Li.  Tony Hu's wonderful "Lao" chain of restaurants have consistently offered the most consistently excellent cuisine in Chicago's Chinatown, and it is...More

title: Good and reasonable
review: I stayed in Chinatown and this small bakery and cafe was a few doors down.  Went for a coconut bun and coffe every morning. Had dinner also , shrimp fried rice.They have the traditional Chinese baked and menu items, all looked delicious. The staff was...very pleasant. If you delight in this type of cuisine, it is worth  it to try. reasonable and tasty.  They also go by Sunlight Cafe.More

title: Is This the Holy Grail of Noodles?
review: OM gosh!!! We ate here at least ten times in six weeks. Took four other groups. Unanimously loved. They make hand stretched noodles as you watch through a little window into the kitchen. FRESH! Enormous portions for $7. I don‚Äôt know how they stay in...business. The potstickers were so delicate and perfectly singed. The little cumin lamb pita lime sandwiches were like $3. The pig elbow sweet and crunchy. I love the sweet and spicy noodles the best. Also love the deep fried vegetable black rice noodles. Mountains of chewy delights for a ridiculously low price. We have been missing this place daily since we returned home......please be there next year!!!More

title: Delish and good portion
review: Biang biang mian was delish and portions were huge. Be prepared to share one bowl or come hungry to finish the food. However, the meat soup with bread was average so you should probably skip it.

title: Fabulous food
review: We have eaten Xian food before, in Xian in China and at Xi'an Famous Foods in New York - so wanted to find a western chinese restaurant. We went early and there werent many people in when we arrived. The waitress 'helped' us with the...menu, suggesting things in addition to our choices. She pushed us into having the lamb skewers which we didnt really want, but as they were only $1 we went along with it - and we were so glad we did - they were fantastic. We also had the fried dumplings, the lamb 'burger', the chilli noodles and the noodles with lamb. They were all really good, and the noodles were just the right consistency/texture, soft but with some bite. We were only in Chicago for 5 nights - and we ate in some great restaurants - but this meal, which was the cheapest by far - is the one I remember the best for being so good. If I ever go back to Chicago - I would eat here at least once.More

title: Worth a stop
review: Friendly, fast service and very reasonable priced. The pork flat bread sandwich was great. I will come back to Chinatown just for another one. The marinated pork knuckle was also good. I was surprised by it being served cold but it was worth trying something...new.More

title: Horrible service!
review: Absolutely terrible service. Walked in and wondered if we sat ourselves, apparently you did. It was out first time there and didn't know, plus no one said anything to us. We had no acknowledgement, no drinks, no order, no hello, nothing. The only time someone...came up to us was when our spoons were brought over and that was it. Server didn't even speak to us then. Servers went to other tables and completely ignored ours. Even when we got up to leave, a server tried to get by us and still said nothing. I have never been treated like this at any restaurant. Unbelievably rude.More

title: A good find
review: My husband and I are always looking for different restaurants to try different food. Never had Xian style food and decided to give it a try. The restaurant does not have much decoration but the food is great! The service is quick. I love the...flat bread with beef. My husband ordered baked flatbread in soup with lamb which is delicious. I also had hand pulled noodle with beef. The noodle is really good but the soup base is not as flavorful as I expected. The prices are reasonable. I would definitely go back in the future to have the flatbread again.More

title: Great Food Quick Bite
review: This is a gem in China town. It offers a street food style noodles and flat bread sandwich. The flavor is not over powering but tasty. Don‚ÄòT expect a formal meal there but I would go back anytime for a quick bite.

title: Just great food
review: Hand pulled noodles mustn't be missed. We tried the pulled noodles with chili and lamb, lamb and cumin flat bread, thin potato slices in sour and spicy sauce, pork pot stickers which reminded us of traditional Chinese dumplings. All of it was spectacular. Place was...filled with locals from Chinatown and lots of University students. Great place. Two of us pigged out for $28.More

title: Delicious
review: My husband and I are plain, American travelers.  We tried this restaurant after staying in Chinatown for the weekend and loved it.  Very friendly service.  They let us know, up front, that they serve authentic food with no chicken or rice options. I had the...hand-stretched noodles and they were absolutely delicious.  My husband had a pork, flat bread that he raved about.  We also noticed that their take out kitchen was very busy, a good sign! If you are looking for authentic, not so pricey and delicious this is certainly a great place to stop!More

title: Good quality but very limited menu
review: The pulled noodle dishes (with lamb and/or other accompaniments) are quite good, but the extremely limited menu is simply too small, too lacking in variety. This may be genuine Xi'an cuisine, but I suspect Xi'an offers more than the handful of dishes here.

title: Does an Authentic Chinese Meal Last Three Hours?
review: Our group wanted to try the hot pot craze, dubbed as a completely authentic Chinese experience. We all love Asian food. About half of our group liked the experience, but not me. Here‚Äôs why:  First of all, the choices of menus were difficult to understand....I don‚Äôt mean the food on the menu, I mean the menus themselves. There are two different menus, an all-you-can-eat and another one, and you can‚Äôt mix and match; if one of your group is starving and wants all-you-can-eat, everyone has to choose that much more expensive option. We had to ask for clarification of ordering instructions over three times. You may have to wait for someone that speaks English well enough to explain it to you, and then you might still not quite understand what happened until you get the check. I am a college graduate and experienced world traveler, and I still had difficulty.   The food choices are not explained well. Three types of lamb and beef were on the menu, each with descriptors such as ‚Äúsupreme‚Äù and ‚Äúextra special‚Äù with different pricing, but no other information to help you decide which you want. We ended up getting one of each and could not tell any difference whatsoever when they were brought to the table. There were scallops and shrimp, which were easy to understand, and ended up being my favorites, my poor brain being too confused. The food itself was obviously very fresh, which is the only good thing I can mention.  Service was awful. We arrived between lunch and dinner, when there were only a few other parties in the whole place, but we had a long wait for each request, not only to receive what we requested (such as drink refills or chopsticks), but to catch a staffer even to ask in the first place!  The hot pot cooking method was fine; I have no problem with that. But give me enough information to choose the foods I want to cook there, and not question what the hell‚Äôs going on.More

title: Great first hot pot experience
review: Visiting Chicago and tried our first hot pot.  Food was delicious and will definitely be seeking out more hot pots.  Service was a little slow but other than that I would recommend this restaurant.

title: Great hotpot experience
review: Located right next the Chinatown gate on Wentworth, I highly recommend this hot pot place. I‚Äôm not sure why this until has 17 reviews but it deserves more.   The prices are reasonable, the broths are great (I had the spicy house broth with no meat),...and the selection is amazing. Think of something you may want in a hot pot and they probably have it.More

title: Great hotpot
review: At the top level of hotspot restaurants in Chinatown. Fresh ingredients, wide range of seasoning sauces, richly flavored broths all add up to a terrific hotpot experience. There are many hotpot restaurants now in Chinatown. This and Mandarin Kitchen are the finest.

title: Visiting Chinatown
review: Had hot pot!  Very healthy, delicious, and filling.  Good place, great service.  In the heart of Chicago's Chinatown.  I will be back soon!

title: Authentic Chinese Food Hands on!
review: I took my cousin who visited me from China to this place for hot pot in this winter weather. We chose for all you can eat ($22.99 per person) with variety of choices from meat, seafood, veggies, tofu, much much more. The material were fresh....Even my cousin said it's authentic Chinese food. The service were good and fast. They do have parking pass for their guests which you can ask.More

title: Disgustingly dirty
review: Went on Saturday 10/28/17, the floor by the bathroom which is near the kitchen is completely flooded.   There was not even an attempt to try to mop it up, all the employees just all walk around like nothing is happening.  Had I seen that before...I started to eat, I would've never eaten there.  That means whatever is on the floor is tracked by everyone on their shoes.  It's beyond disgusting.   Everything is dirty, the entrance carpet is gross with water leak and garbage, the sauce counter looks like its never cleaned in ages.  How this place passes health inspection is the mystery.  Stay away and let the health department shut this place down.More

title: Cook and eat together!
review: The hot pot experience was fun and different as well as delicious. They bring you your choice of broths and they boil on your table. Then you add your choice of ingredients ordered 2 at a time and enjoy! They offered all you can eat...for a not cheap price but if you can use it as a main meal of the day and new experience it is well worth it.More

title: Perfect for eating with a group of friends
review: Shabu shabu or hotpot is always preferrable to eat with friends. My visit was back in January of this year (2017) but I remember the wonderful experience I had eating at Little Lamb with a group of girlfriends. There must've been 10 of us. It...was my going away as I was moving out of state. We ordered the eat all you can and it was perfect. We ordered non-stop. My friends kept cooking and I kept eating. The vegetables were fresh and the meat so tender. The servers were very attentive. It is a must-visit. I will come back when I visit family and friends.More

title: Mostly Authentic Hot Pot
review: Well, this place was quite good. I have lived in China full time for the last ten years, and have eaten at plenty of hot pot restaurants. My wife, who is Chinese, also thought it was pretty good.   For those of you that don't know...about hot pot, the waiters will serve you raw food, you will cook it yourself, you will share a pot with other people, and it will be spicy (I personally thought it was not that hot).   Why is it not entirely authentic? 1. The meat is better than the meat in China (good thing). 2. The super spicy hot pot was not that hot (in addition to my wife, my sister and her boyfriend who have never eaten hot pot were able to eat it without a problem (bad thing). 3. The service is not as good as the hot pot restaurants in China (Hai Di Lao, La Fu, Ba Nv). There were only two waiters when we were there. However, this is not really a complaint. You don't need a waiter to enjoy a hot pot experience.  Looking at the menu of the other Little Sheep, which is right around the corner, Little Lamb had much more items on the menu. Little Sheep had maybe 18 things on the menu (not enough for hot pot). While it is the more famous hot pot restaurant in China, they have clearly Americanized the menu (boring)!  Overall, my family and I had a great time and felt stuffed. Everyone should really try hot pot, because it is primarily meat and vegetables in soup. I can't give Little Lamb a five because the hot pot wasn't that spicy. But that doesn't mean that others won't think it is spicy. Have fun and give something different a try!More

title: Great Place to Try Something New
review: We are by no means experienced eaters when it comes to this style of food. Being a fan of various youtubers who visit Hot Pot and Shabu-Shabu restaurants, I really wanted a chance to try one, and we selected Little Lamb for our first adventure...More

title: Great Chinese hotpot
review: Little Lamb is ((along with Mandarin Kitchen) at the top oh Chinatown  hotpot restaurants. You can get spicy or non/spicy broth, or a half and half bowl to satisfy all tastes. The non spicy one is richly seasoned. You cook the ingredients at the table...More

title: Would not come back!
review: If you are not familiar with "hot pot" dining experience I'd say pass this place. We went here to try something new and was that a mistake, it was just weird, hot inside since you cook at your table and smelled a little funny. Our...More

title: Tight space; average hot pot meal
review: Visiting from the bay area (California), this Hot Pot restaurant is just average.  The ingredients for cooking were ok/average; but the broth (we ordered 2 broth) Spicy Herbal was not spicy enough and the Herbal was bland.  They place the food trays at the table...More

title: Delicious Hot Pot and great service!
review: Moving to Chicago alone, I have been venturing around town trying different treats and Little Lamb was definitely a treat!!! I went alone (obvs) and ordered a HUGE amount of food- MOngolian Spicy broth, and regular broth; Selected Beef and lamb, Bok Choy, Watercress, Seaweed,...More

title: Great Hot Pot Restaurant
review: Little Lamb is a superb hot pot restaurant - along with Mandarin Kitchen the finest in Chicago.  The wide variety of condiments to make your own dipping sauce is extraordinary, and the menu selection is huge.

title: Finally Chicago gets a hotpot restaurant
review: I moved to Chicago 10 years ago from Boston. And while I've loved exploring restaurants here, there was one thing lacking in my opinion: a true hot pot restaurant. Sure, you could have ordered hot pot at a number of places, but that's different from...More

title: Very Authentic
review: Having travelled numerous times to China and enjoyed the various regional hot pots, Little Lamp does a wonderful job remaining true to the culture.  The owners are inviting and have done an amazing job with the ambiance.

title: Hot Pot at it's finest....
review: You either like hot pot or you don't. This is a great place but really specializes in Chinese hot pot. For a really good hot pot- it's about the broth, freshness of ingredients and the dipping sauce. This place really delivers on all three. Wide...More

title: Good Hot Pot With Very Professional Staff
review: Meeting an out of town friend in Chicago Chinatown and decided to try this place (a late lunch around 1:30 pm on Saturday).  The place is clean and the wait staff is friendly and professional.  We ordered a herb broth and spicy broth combined pot....More

title: (North Ave site) Food is good, but unwelcoming & unfriendly staff was awful
review: (This review pertains to their restaurant on North Ave) Soups were enjoyed by all, but the taint on the restaurant and dining experience is the staff. I absolutely do not need an unctuous server or host/hostess, but the absence of any niceness from the time...we walked in to the time we left made a lightning impression of hostility and rudeness. Don't need to think twice before NOT going back or even recommending this place to others...will not go back and I encourage others not to go as well until they change the culture and customer service. There are equally good other places to go for pho.  eg Dong Ky in the city.More

title: Cafe Hoang in Chinatown is closed. Pho Cafe replace it.
review: Pho Cafe has taken over the space. The Vietnamese-Chinese food is very good. One of the better places to go for Pho in Chinatown  from Cafe Hoang's website: Chinatown Location Close Hello everyone!  After 12 amazing years in Chinatown, we‚Äôve decided to make the difficult...decision to close our Chinatown location. The reason for this decision is to combine efforts with our brother to focus on expanding Cafe Hoang‚Äôs first location on Argyle in Uptown.  We want to take the time to thank each and everyone of our customers and supporters through all these years. While this is an end to our Chinatown location, we hope to see you all at Cafe Hoang on North Ave and Cafe Hoang on Argyle. We will be expanding our menu selections at the Cafe Hoang on North Ave location to include customers favorites from Chinatown.More

title: Cheap eats. Good Pho.  No Frills.
review: This was a first:  dining in a restaurant in January inside where I had to keep my coat and hat on during my entire meal.  This place is really for those on a tight budget as this place barely had heat and I was freezing...sitting near the big window in front! Also, don‚Äôt look to closely at the dirty ceilings, floors or the walls plastered with hand written signs like ‚Äúno splitting checks‚Äù or ‚Äúbathrooms for customers only‚Äù which by the way, the ladies room was out of order.  We should have realized this was a no-frills place as it was full of college aged adults on a busy Saturday night in Chinatown and the one or two servers were very harried.  Service improved once our order was placed and the Pho was good and had well-developed flavors.   My husband said his soft-shelled crabs were almost ‚Äúoff‚Äù.  I guess this place, while it has many items including Thai dishes, is good for a bowl of hot pho at a cheap price with absolutely no frills dining.   I would not return as I don‚Äôt want clumps of dust bunnies dangling from the vents over my Pho but for a cheap bowl of decent pho on the go, this may be fine for some.More

title: Pho and more
review: We have frequented Cafe Huong a few since Check, Please! reviewed it some years back. The interior is nothing to gawk at but the food is consistent. And our most recent trip yielded a toddler/drink disaster, which wasn't embarrassing thanks to the staffs quick and...friendly service. The photos on the wall are helpful but could use some updating as fading and stains are reflected however this has no bearing on their food. Pho, lemongrass rice, chicken fried rice and Thai ice tea are the favorites.More

title: Unimpressed for the 1st time
review: Meh, Was disappointed for the very 1st time. I think "Saigon Pho" in Oak Park was much better than this. The staff did not seem interested in serving the customers including our table. In fact they looked angry to serve you based on body language...and facial expressions. They even served an Ice Vietnamese Coffee with Milk in which the waitress spilled the ice glass to serve in. The only good think that tasted good was the Spring Shrimp Vegetable rolls and the Crab Rangoon my friend had ordered. The Pho was ok but for me ordering the "Pho House Special" I expected a lot more combination of meats. This is the 1st and last time I would come back again. Surprise they have the nerve to expect a 15% tip for service since they are fairly new in Oak Park which left a bitter taste to my mouth if not bad impressionMore

title: I eat here way too much.
review: I eat here way too much, and I am not sorry. Try the pho. It is happiness in a bowl. My son loves number 46.

title: Delicious
review: I stumbled upon this place while walking to the bus and I am so glad I did. I ordered an appetizer and one of the Vietnamese soups and everything was absolutely delicious. Right amount of spice and flavor.  Crisp, fresh ingredients! It was such a...great meal. The staff was absolutely wonderful as well, friendly and competent. I'd love to go back on my next trip to Chicago.More

title: Vietnamese and Thai Restaurant
review: This Chinatown location is way better than the one on Argyle St. in Uptown. This location is a wonderful spot just off the main drag on Cermark. Chef Jason and his wife have been open for 10 years now, Cooking. Their food speaks for itself....Its simple, it smells good, looks good, is good. Every item I've tried, Good stuff, I have been Wowed and Enjoyed! Casual place. Order by menu or picture on the walls! Service is quick. Hard work has paid off. And the two of them are just darn nice people! and we like nice...don't we! It's one go to place I keep on my restaurant rotation that never disappoints. Good job Guys. That's why I give Caf'e Hoang in Chinatown four stars.More

title: Thanks Check Please
review: We chose  Cafe Hoang  because of Check Please.We haven't been to Chinatown for years.After Cafe Hoang visit  we will return soon.Our waitress wasn't  real charming or efficient but she was authentic  as as the food. My seafood combo w veggie  was superb  w huge oysters...and shrimp in a good brown sauce.My wife's veggie tofu was a  fav of hers in  Blackbean sauce.Byob with Lucky Buddha made it a pleasant evening in Chitown.Vietnamese and Thai menu very diverse.Easy access and parking .More

title: Vietnamese Foodie and Pho Paradise (and a BYOB spot)
review: If you're a fan of Vietnamese food you will be in heaven at Caf√© Hoang!  The restaurant is conveniently located in Chinatown and easy to find.  A stroll through Chinatown and a peek in the shops is an adventure in itself, so it's what I...call a BONUS location!  Street parking can be scarce at times but just park in the big pay lot a block away or take the Red Line into the neighborhood.  If you're not sure what to order, there are photographs of the dishes all along the walls of the restaurant to help you make up your mind or you can watch what they're bringing out to other tables.  We had the #1 spring rolls and #5 Vietnamese pancakes for appetizers.  The #5 was an ABSOLUTELY AMAZING flavor explosion and I would be tempted to have this as my main dish sometime.  We had the beef pho soup and it was very, very good.  We also had the #27 fried egg noodle dish with chicken and it was also very, very good.  The restaurant was simple and clean.  The service was friendly and speedy.  We had to ask exactly how we were supposed to eat the #5 and they were very helpful (you wrap the pancake, carrots, cucumber and basil leaves up in a lettuce leaf and dip it into some heavenly sauce).  The cost is reasonable: appetizers are $3-$6 and mains are minimum $7.  It would be fun to have dinner here sometime and take advantage of the BYOB option.  I can't wait to get back to Caf√© Hoang to try more items from the menu.  See you there!!!More

title: Good lunch
review: We had lunch here after finding it on the trip advisor city app.  Good food, good value & good staff.

title: First Vietnamese Food - VaVaVoom
review: Despite visiting Chinatown our whole lives, we had never attempted the Vietnamese food there or anywhere in Chicago.  We decided it was time and we reviewed an older episode of a local foodie show called Check Please to get some ideas on what to order....More

title: delish and comfy too!
review: i love vietnamese food and since i live on the south side i was wishing for a place closer to me than having to drive all the way up towards argyle to get my food fix. this place was awesome great fresh food,fantastic prices,  clean...More

title: No chop suey or chirpy servers
review: Negative reviewers here, must like chop suey & ‚Äúhow‚Äôs your food tastin‚Äô‚Äù American servers.   Nothing wrong with Chop Suey. (Visit the Chinese-American museum around the corner, to see the role of that Americanized dish in Chinese-American  economic survival history.)  Nothing wrong with chirpy servers either....But‚Ä¶  ‚Ä¶ if you want the real thing, come here. It is gourmet Cantonese, with mind-bending variety. As a bonus, get that authenticity & quality at cheap-digs prices!  ‚ÄúSurly‚Äù service is part of the experience. Chinese servers would rather get it right the first time, than have to ask. If you want something, they expect YOU to ask. And many simply do not speak English well‚Äîwhich bodes well for authenticity!More

title: Average Chinese restaurant in Chinatown
review: This is just an ordinary restaurant in Chinatown. The place is big. Food is just ordinary for Chinese restaurants compared to what I have tried before; nothing special. They practice social distancing and price is just fine.

title: Amazing!
review: Let me start by saying everything we had was fabulous. And we tried a lot of things. We ended up taking a lot of stuff home because everything looked so good. Prices were fabulous, food was out of this world and there was convenient parking...a block away. I‚Äôm definitely going back next time I‚Äôm in Chicago!   I doubt if I can remember everything we had but we had shrimp eggrolls, salty fish fried rice with chicken, Siu mai ,Pan fried turn up cake, sticky rice,  shrimp dumplings, steamed barbecue pork bun, stuffed bean curd skin with pork,  And a few more things like that I can‚Äôt recall. It was all fabulous. The picture man you made it easy for a Gweilo.  Certainly didn‚Äôt hurt that I was there with my Chinese relatives because there are things I probably wouldn‚Äôt have tried if they hadn‚Äôt told me to. The biggest surprise favorite for me was the panfried turnip cake.More

title: Uu favorite Chinese restaurant
review: I eat here when I can when I'm in Chi town... The food is excellent and the serving size is very large, enough for two.

title: In Many Ways Amazing
review: Portion size was amazing. The food tasted great. The restaurant was clean. It was busy with locals so it is respected as a good location. Chinese table sevice sometimes comes off as disrepectful but often I feel it is language barrier or a different communication...style. My service I felt was not the best at times but upon leaving I was given kind smiles and thanks for coming in. I think as a customer I do not need to have  attitude or certain expectations. I treat serving staff well and it is returned. This was the case at this establishment.More

title: When the customers are Chinese, it's probably a good Chinese Restaurant
review: We arrived here on a Sunday just after noon and the place was happily filled with groups of Chinese adults enjoying the food. I noted that it was either middle aged women or Middle aged men grouped at tables - not the sort of family...Sunday dinner pattern that I had assumed.    The entrance is a bit grim with its tanks of eel, fish and over-crowded lobster, dim lighting, and narrowl door.  The inside is quite pleasant with clean big tables and mirrors placed on either side of the room in a way that makes it seem a lot larger.  They have both Dim Sum and a more conventional menu of entrees.  Being tourists, we did a little of both and our waitress was very accommodating.    There were language problems that prevented much conversation about the nature of entrees that were unknown to us so we settled on orange chicken plus three orders off the Dim Sum menu.   All arrived hot and in generous portions.  Prices were very reasonable.More

title: Agree with Lisa F who reviewed on May 30th.
review: Very poor customer service.  Food is okay.  Price is reasonable.  But its just a really bad feeling when you get mistreated by the staff.  Very disrespectful.  It's almost like they don't really care.

title: Don't eat here
review: So, first off, the food is decent, for which I would give 3 stars.   Despite most of the restaurant being empty, the hostess (if you can call her that as she didn't smile or talk to us, really) refused to seat us for 10 minutes...as she didn't want us to take up a larger table (despite the fact that it was mid-afternoon and the chance of several large groups coming in for the larger tables was non-existent). We should have left at that point. Also, our server dropped the lid of our soup takeout container on the floor and then gave it to us to use, dirty and oily from whatever was on the floor, because she thought we hadn't seen her drop it. When I asked for another lid, she seemed annoyed. Finally, I noticed the same lady watching me intently count out the tip as she pretended to sweep the floor, making me uncomfortable). I had put down a tip of just shy of 15% on the pre-tax amount and she came over the demand that we put down 15% on the post-tax amount becauseMore

title: May Flower - - Fresh and Delicious!
review: I ate here while attending the NSTA conference downtown.  I had the walnut beef.  Being from South Carolina, I never get this kind of Chinese food back home.  This was the real deal.  I left full and very satisfied needless to say!

title: Great food.  Service NOT Great.
review: We ate at a couple places during our recent trip to Chicago.  This place had, by far, the best food.  The dim sum was so good.  Service was slow and I did not like how the food came out at different times.  All in all...they brought our dishes out at four different times.  12 minutes after they brought our first order, did they finally bring the last order.  The place was packed and we waited 10 minutes for a table.  After being seated we waited over 10 minutes to see our server.  After our food was brought to us we never saw server again until she brought our bill.  Restrooms were dirty.  Terrible smell of stale urine in the men's room.  Looked like it hadn't been cleaned in months!  Overall, the food here was unbelievably good.More

title: Great Chinese goodies
review: Great food and really great prices.  Best food in the Chinatown area. The plates are over flowing with tasty goodness.

title: Good Food, Unfriendly Service
review: We saw a few locals parking their car so we asked which place in the area had good food.  We were directed here.  Food was actually good and very reasonably priced.  The service, however, was not good.  Although the waitress was not neglectful, no one...More

title: Fried smelts
review: The restaurant is located in the old part of Chinatown, which was quite desolate and empty the Sunday I was there. I've never experienced and empty Chinatown on a Sunday before or any of day of the week for that matter. Ignore the unwelcoming entrance...More

title: YummY... come & try it!
review: hubby & i been coming here couple times every month. we loved their foods and they open late at night. we have same waiter every time we come his so good. must try their soft shell crab YUMMY!!!

title: Excellent Food..Open Late too!!
review: This place was rec. by the Chinatown Hotel staff. Wonderful food, reasonable price and next door to a shop called K-POP!! Neat

title: Horrible Customer Service and Food!!  DON'T GO THERE!!
review: There are so many amazing restaurants in Chicago's Chinatown, PLEASE DO NOT waste your time or money going to this place!!  IT IS THE WORST!!  On the very same block there are more restaurants than I can count and every other one I have been...More

title: Food comes out as soon as it's done
review: Restaurant in Chinatown, I liked it a lot. We got our food as soon as it was done, and it tasted great. Our server was great too, especially since she was the only server that night.

title: lunch
review: it delivers to university so very convenient. the varieties are also impressive, and tastes are fine for cantonese

title: morning breakfast
review: good place with lots to choose from, typical Hong Kong/China morning breakfast items. Fresh and well cooked, price on the higher side as compare to nearby restaurant that serves similar food items. Services are average, not unusual for this type of place in this neighborhood....Overall, a recommended place to eat, they have regular Chinese food dishes and pot luck style of cook and eat by the table as well. Smaller place packed with lots of food items, including a bakery for all baked goodies.More

title: Excellent noodles in the New Chinatown section
review: We could not make up our minds.  First, on where to eat, then, after picking Sweet Station, on what to eat.  We chose this restaurant based on the reviews posted on the window.  We're glad we did.  While the restaurant is small, the menu is...HUGE.  If you're not sure what something is, ask.  Look at what others are eating.  If it looks interesting, ask the diner what it is.  Portions are large.  If you're not especially ravenous you may want to share your entr√©e.  We ordered fried squid and potstickers for appetizers.  The squid was almost melt-in-your-mouth good.  I know that sounds weird, considering squid can be chewy but the breading was light and the squid tender.  The potstickers were among the best I've ever had.  We both love noodles and had a hard time choosing.  I went with a Hong Kong style stir fry while my companion had the gummy noodles.  My noodles were similar to spaghetti in shape but that's where the similarity ended.  I could tell they were made fresh.  The sauce was delicious and the beef tender.  The gummy noodles turned out to be chow fun, which we hadn't had in quite a while (non of our local Chinese places serve it).  It was so good.  We are good eaters but neither of us could finish our plates.  Were we not in a hotel without a microwave we would have taken the leftovers with us.  I also had a Hong Kong iced green tea that was very good.  Service was friendly and fast.  Prices were reasonable.  Don't forget to get your parking validated if you're parked for 2 hours or less.More

title: Next time we'll share an entree
review: I ordered the vegetarian fried rice, which could have been served in a large mixing bowl--as good as it was, I could only eat about a quarter of my portion.  My dining companion had a beef/vegetable entr√©e, with rice, and also couldn't eat everything. Probably...a small serving of soup for each of us and one entr√©e would have been about right.  Service was very good, food delicious.  We were at the Chinatown location, and noticed that it was quite popular for lunch--more crowded than some of the other restaurants we passed, which we considered a hopeful sign.  We got here via Water Taxi, it's a bit of a hike to the restaurant area on a heat-advisory day in July (I'm a 77-year-old-lady, so perhaps others would find it just a quick stroll).More

title: Great Wings!!
review: Great Wings and Smoothies - the honey garlic and salt and pepper wings are still amazing - full of flavor, not soggy, but crisp.  The pineapple smoothies were excellent as well.  This time around, we tried the won-ton soup - personally hated it.   The wontons...had a weird flavor I couldn't identify, not what I'm used to.  Some may like it.More

title: Rubbery Everything....
review: Food was okay. Not sure how boiled chicken mixed in a wok with sauce is considered Chinese food, but seems to be the norm in Chicago.

title: the taste is up to standard, the price is reasonable
review: We try 2 times for the breakfast there, the taste of the food is up to standard compared to those in Hong Kong, the price is reasonable.

title: Maybe the service was a fluke?
review: They totally forgot the meal of the one person who would review the restaurant in our group, so take that how you will.  The food was a little expensive for being so heavy on veggies, but was good otherwise.  Might be worth a go, but...there are probably better places with similar menus around.More

title: Good Chinese Food
review: They serve good food!! Don't forget to try their breakfast, it is a big deal, it is one of the best restaurant in Chinatown.

title: Authentic Chinese-our exchange student said so!
review: Took our exch student here before he went back home and he was delighted to eat food that was similar to his local fare (outside Hong Kong).  We ordered walnut shrimp (American Chinese dish), sweet n sour shrimp, beef with vegs and rice noodles, crab...More

title: BIG Disappointment
review: We had take out from here before and it was quite good, so for this trip to Chinatown decided to eat at the restaurant.  My daughter's pan fried noodles were swimming in oil.  I was going to get the chicken with broccoli but decided to...More

title: Great Chinese
review: My wife and I had walked all afternoon in Chicago from our hotel at North Michigan Ave and East Grand to Chinatown enjoying the sights along the way. By the time we got to Chinatown we were tired and very hungry. As we walked along...More

title: Restaurant now CLOSED
review: This restaurant is now closed. I was very sad to find that they were no long in business when we took a trip to Chinatown recently. They were the best for good food and ok prices.

title: Great Food and Delivers to Hilton Chicago!
review: Four stars for the food plus an extra star for being one of the only szechuan places -- I called 4 or 5 -- which delivers to Hilton Chicago!!! It had been a long travel day so I was set on not having to leave...the hotel for food. Ordered the Dried Chili chicken (Chong Ching chicken at NYC places) and it was fantastic -- perfectly fried pieces, well spiced with szechuan spices and dried chilis. Also had the Tony's Famous Dumplings which are huge and very filling -- the meat in them tastes like the meat from soup dumplings -- amazing flavors. They come with two dipping sauces; I only used the spicy red pepper flake sauce which added a perfect amount of spiciness. The Szechuan string beans were fine but not spectacular. I will keep this in mind for future trips to Chicago. If I lived in Chicago, this would become a regular thing.More

title: Authentic Chinese Food
review: We went there with a family visiting from China.  You never know is it authentic or Americanized Chinese food.   This is as authentic as it gets per our friends.   We ordered several dishes and shared them all.  We had egg drop soup that had a...touch of chicken broth and corn in it.   A bit different but added flavor depth and texture.  Next we had something I am not sure what it was called but it was a broth with stuffed pork dumplings.   Flavor was out outstanding.   Next we had duck soup.   For the main dishes we shared Peking duck and Mongolian lamb.   Both were outstanding.  Staff was a bit hard to communicate with but thankfully we had our guess with that bridge any communication gap.   This is a must if you want authentic not Americanized food.More

title: One of my favorite places
review: This restaurant is one of my favorite restaurants in Chinatown. I think the chef from Lao Yu Ju switched over to here because I recognize a lot of the dishes and they are quite good.

title: worse food and worse service
review: I introduced my friends to Lao Beijing but ending with a big disappointment. The waiter kept asking us to repeat the order, it took a long time to serve the food, and finally the food is getting more worse than before, the service was bad,...and then, i knew why there is less and less customers in their restaurant.More

title: The BEST Peking Duck
review: I have had Peking duck in probably five restaurants in Chicago and 25-30 nationwide.  This is the best Peking duck that I have ever had.  It can be served in the traditional three course manner or in the now (somewhat unfortunately) more common single course...manner.More

title: Decent food
review: Hidden away in a rundown pedestrian mall with insufficient parking. Can't even tell which restaurant you're entering; each one has multiple unmarked doors. Once inside, the decor was unimpressive. Seating is close together, chairs are too low for the tables. Our table was unsteady. We...were a party of 7, so we tried several entrees and appetizers. Everything was pretty good, but fell short of what we were hoping for in an authentic Chinatown experience. not worth the effort.More

title: Food of North
review: Yes, I am from Northern part of China and I love the food here in Lao Beijing. Our family visited it a lot and love it.

title: Still good, different ownership
review: No longer one of Tony Hu's restaurants, Lao Beijing continues to be a good option in Chinatown, but not, perhaps, one of the best. I have had some good noodle dishes here, and fine seafood choices as well. The menu lacks the imagination and breadth...of some of Chinatown's finest, but this remains a better-than-average choice with authentic Beijing style cuisine.More

title: Bad food
review: Three dishes ordered: one was inedible, two others just not good. Not a place you'd even bother to order in from. Tea was nice though

title: Appetizers the clear winners
review: My son wanted to go to China town so I did some research online looking for a place that served Szechuan food and ended up choosing Lao Bejing based on a number of reviews.  Let hits the three areas; d√©cor, food and service. D√©cor.  Well,...More

title: Delicious!!
review: Located in Chinatown square, we selected this restaurant on a whim. There are many places to eat while visiting here and I'm sure they are all pretty good. Lao Beijing turned out to be an excellent choice. For starters they bring out a plate of...More

title: The Quality Has Gone Down...
review: A few years ago, I thought the food here was much better, but things have slipped at Lao Beijing, e.g. I can recognize a frozen factory pot sticker a mile away. The rhythm of the kitchen was off, items arrived too fast (too much at...More

title: good fresh food and fast service
review: from the outside this may not look like a place to go to but once inside its a different story. Servers are friendly and know the menu. They are quick. The food comes fast too. Options range from mild to spicy and from sea food...More

title: satisfied
review: We were here on a Wednesday evening about 7:00 pm.  The restaurant was about 1/2 full and we were seated and served promptly.  Very complete menu with some interesting specialties for the adventerous.  Meals were very good and price reasonable.  We would come here again.

title: Just so so, won't go back
review: Just like my experiences in their sister restaurants Lao Sze Chuan and Lao Yunnan, food quality is just so so, not worth the time.

title: Good. Lots of choices. Fast service.
review: An extensive menu. Good service. Convenient location in Chinatown. We went on a Sunday and expected to have to wait, but were served our food quickly.

title: Good food, bad service
review: We had a Saturday night dinner there.  We showed up early (5:30) at a time they were not packed, yet the service was still incredibly slow.  The food, however, was very good (though not good enough to offset the service).  There are better restaurants along...More

title: Excellent Beijing style cuisine
review: Lao Beijing is another of Tony Hu's excellent restaurants in Chicago's Chinatown. While it has dishes from all of the provinces, its specialty is the type of cuisine found in Beijing, including a number of terrific noodle dishes. In addition, a beef and mushroom casserole...More

title: Great Cantonese Food
review: Stopped here on the Chinatown Walking Food Tour. Had Peking Duck, which was great. The hoison sauce made it a look little too sweet so if you want to taste more of the duck, take it easy on the sauce. Otherwise another great authentic Chinese...More

title: Good food; poor service
review: About 3 weeks ago my wife and I "discovered" this restaurant and liked it very much. We determined that there was a party room upstairs and reserved a table for 12 for my upcoming birthday. One week ago we ate there again and found out that they had no record of the reservation; we re-made it. Yesterday I phoned and again was told that they had no record of a reservation; again I re-made it. Today they did have the table ready, but the service was only fair to poor. Only one waitress was assigned to us, and we continually had to ask for things that should have been pretty obvious, like re-filling the rice bowl. Tea was never provided. We started eating at 4 pm on Saturday, hardly a particularly busy time.I really don't think the waitress had a communication problem; her English was very good.The food was pretty good. My one concern with this restaurant is that a lot of what they deep-fry (which they do very well) tends to be terribly over-breaded. Yesterday I tried to fax our desired order to the restaurant, only to find that the fax number had been disconnected. I asked for the phone number of Tony Hu, the owner of this and a bunch of other Chinatown-Chicago restaurants, and was given a number that is not in service.In all, I'd recommend this restaurant for its food but don't go expecting very attentive service.

title: GOOD RESTAURANT.
review: I often went to this restaurant with my wife, some dishes are really good, it is not so spicy like Lao Sichuan, I like the pork they cooked. Also the service is not bad. It is better for a Family event, since the entr√©e is always too very heavy to finish for solo or couple. It is not easy to take many tastes like a Chinese Buffet result. But anyway, it is not a bad option in Chicago Chinatown, at least, it won't let u down.

title: A Gem in Chinatown.
review: I discovered this gem on Good Friday in 2013. I've been back 5 times. As a widow with no escort on a permanent basis, it's not always easy to find a comfortable "go to restaurant". This is mine. Last night for example, we left the selection to our friend and manager, Michael.....superb. It was a "royal treat". Last Friday, I brought 4 friends and let him pick the menu. The noodles are hand made, the sauces are divine. The baby bok choy with mushrooms is the essence of elegance. The lamb omg. And I can't forget the soup dumplings, which is why we went in the beginning. Oh, why was Good Friday important. The velvet scallops. I can still remember how they tasted. Ah, what a restaurant.

title: So many, so much to choose from!
review: Chicago's China Town is always fun to visit. There are so many restaurants there to choose from. A local recommended Lao Beijing to us. Lucky us! Michael is a delight and you can't go wrong with his recommendations. Go for the special crispy shrimp and the Beijing noodles. Yum!

title: Very Good In Restaurant Experience
review: The restaurant was absolutely packed and the service was a bit slow but a fun experience nonetheless. We walked in and found a seat for ourselves right by the door. We have visited China five times so we were hoping for the authentic flavored we knew from our trips. It was not but it was also better than the typical Chinese we get here in the states. Hands down, the best dish we had was the chive dumplings. They are boiled and the wrap is so deliciously soft. The filling tastes very authentic and yummy. The ma po tofu was beautiful but just way too hot (I had requested medium but it was still too hot). The tofu noodles with chicken were delicate and Tony's special dumplings were ok. One recommendation is to avoid the pork potstickers. They had no flavor and the dough was thicker than I use at home. Interestingly, the sesame chicken was fabulous and I did not think much of it when it was ordered as that is typically such a sweet dish here. We would try this restaurant again or probably Lao Shanghai.

title: A stop on the Chicago Food Planet tour
review: Delicious Mandarin food!  We will definitely be back.  A stop on the the Chicago Food Planet tour!  From the North region of China, delicious noodles and dumplings!

title: Order Beijing Duck
review: We stopped here on a Chinatown food tour several months ago and finally were able to get back. We got a table right away on a Sunday mid afternoon and the wait staff was attentive and quick. After bring us some very tasty spicy cabbage (and more cold water) we were served our Beijing Duck which included Fried Duck and a giant bowl of Duck Soup. The Beijing Duck was as wonderful as we remembered it to be. The restaurant was clean - the bathroom, not so much. Other than that, the experience was good!

title: Terrible food via delivery
review: I'm rating food I got as a delivery only. I haven't visited the restaurant itself. But I was excited to try Lao Beijing as I'm a big fan of getting delivery from Lao Hunan. I assumed that this restaurant would have a similar quality being from the same esteemed Tony Hu group. Not so. Food was extremely greasy. The same salt & pepper tofu dish that is delicious at Hunan was served up fried to a crisp. Rice cake dish was very bland (and again, greasy). Never again. I guess it's back to my old favorite.

title: Nice meal
